description: The Microsoft Azure Virtual Machine course covers the foundational knowledge you need to implement an Azure Virtual Machine. The course is geared toward system administrators, who currently have systems in Azure or support local servers and want to transition over to Azure. One should expect to learn how to deploy virtual machines into Windows Azure, different configurations of those servers and how to manage them, the process of how to back up and restore a server and other features in Azure that can be used to supplement a virtual machine.
name: Azure Virtual Machine
subtitle: Azure VM

00:25:12.253 --> 00:25:17.980
>> [LAUGH]
>> And we needed them 24 hours a day.

543
00:25:17.980 --> 00:25:20.611
Now, well that's not right.

544
00:25:20.611 --> 00:25:25.495
Sorry, for my hours here, I need to put
in, it's the amount of hours, well,

545
00:25:25.495 --> 00:25:30.689
like here it's tell me 100 servers that
are A4's would cost me $72 an hour.

546
00:25:30.689 --> 00:25:32.430
It's just kind of listing
it per month here.

547
00:25:32.430 --> 00:25:35.494
So basically, I need to say like
24 hours a day times 31 days,

548
00:25:35.494 --> 00:25:37.074
which I don't know what that is.

549
00:25:37.074 --> 00:25:38.235
Do you know what that is?

550
00:25:38.235 --> 00:25:41.195
>> 24 times 31 [CROSSTALK]
I'm not good at math.

551
00:25:41.195 --> 00:25:42.808
[LAUGH]
>> So 24 times 31,

552
00:25:42.808 --> 00:25:46.152
oh that was the default when
I deleted that like a moron.

553
00:25:46.152 --> 00:25:47.115
There we go.
>> [LAUGH]

554
00:25:47.115 --> 00:25:48.749
>> So if I have 100 of these servers,

555
00:25:48.749 --> 00:25:50.771
it's gonna cost me $53,000 a month.

556
00:25:50.771 --> 00:25:56.097
Now that sounds really expensive,
but if you've got 100 servers,

557
00:25:56.097 --> 00:26:02.590
if they each cost $8,000,
that's $800,000, 50,000 a month.

558
00:26:02.590 --> 00:26:04.831
You divide that up,
it kind of breaks even after two years.

559
00:26:04.831 --> 00:26:08.100
It all kind of boils down to that.

560
00:26:08.100 --> 00:26:10.850
But you can specify and kind of get
an idea of what that's gonna to cost.

561
00:26:10.850 --> 00:26:14.954
Now this tool's not terribly advanced
like I can't specify a bunch of different

562
00:26:14.954 --> 00:26:15.870
instance sizes.

563
00:26:15.870 --> 00:26:20.838
So Microsoft has another tool that, let's
see, do I have it open here somewhere?

564
00:26:20.838 --> 00:26:22.550
I don't, but I have it downloaded.

565
00:26:22.550 --> 00:26:27.435
Microsoft pool tool out there called,
I've got it floating here somewhere, here,

566
00:26:27.435 --> 00:26:30.810
the Microsoft Azure Cost Estimator.

567
00:26:30.810 --> 00:26:32.989
You can go to Microsoft site and
download it, it's free,

568
00:26:32.989 --> 00:26:34.064
you load it on your machine.

569
00:26:34.064 --> 00:26:36.655
And what it will do,
is it will scan your network.

570
00:26:36.655 --> 00:26:38.722
It'll scan the servers on your network.

571
00:26:38.722 --> 00:26:42.827
And it will catalog them, how much memory
they have, how many cores they have,

572
00:26:42.827 --> 00:26:44.747
how much hard drive space they have.

573
00:26:44.747 --> 00:26:48.243
And then it will use the exact data
from your actual data center to

574
00:26:48.243 --> 00:26:52.010
generate a pricing sheet and
tell you exactly how much it would cost.

575
00:26:52.010 --> 00:26:56.340
Because I might have some servers with
two cores and some with eight cores.

576
00:26:56.340 --> 00:26:58.610
I might have some servers with
20 gigs of hard drive space,

577
00:26:58.610 --> 00:27:01.480
I might have some servers with 20
terabytes of hard drive space.

578
00:27:01.480 --> 00:27:04.810
Might have some with 2 gigs of RAM and
some with 24 gigs of RAM.

579
00:27:04.810 --> 00:27:08.021
So it's going to figure that out and
give me the exact pricing,

580
00:27:08.021 --> 00:27:11.717
and while I'm thinking about memory,
I meant to mention something back

581
00:27:11.717 --> 00:27:14.640
here on one of these pages that I was on,
what page was it?

582
00:27:14.640 --> 00:27:15.465
This one.

583
00:27:15.465 --> 00:27:20.584
These weird memory sizes,
you guys might have noticed like 3.5 gigs.

584
00:27:20.584 --> 00:27:22.348
Why doesn't it say 4 gigs?

585
00:27:22.348 --> 00:27:25.227
Or 1.75, why doesn't it say 2 gigs?

586
00:27:25.227 --> 00:27:27.504
7 gigs, why not 8 gigs of RAM?

587
00:27:27.504 --> 00:27:32.348
What happened to the nice normal
memory sizes that we're used to, 1,

588
00:27:32.348 --> 00:27:34.863
2, 4, 8, 16, 32 and so on?

589
00:27:34.863 --> 00:27:40.984
Well, what Microsoft's doing is they're
actually deducting the memory required for

590
00:27:40.984 --> 00:27:42.340
the base OS.

591
00:27:42.340 --> 00:27:45.300
They don't wanna falsely
advertise to you that hey,

592
00:27:45.300 --> 00:27:49.150
you get 8 gigs of RAM when the host
OS is eating a gig of that RAM.

593
00:27:49.150 --> 00:27:51.100
And so
you actually only get 7 gigs usable.

594
00:27:51.100 --> 00:27:54.536
So that's what they're showing here is
what's the usable memory available for

595
00:27:54.536 --> 00:27:55.153
your system.

596
00:27:55.153 --> 00:27:58.860
The minimum system requirements for
Windows Server is 1 gig of RAM, and

597
00:27:58.860 --> 00:28:00.819
that's why this starts at 0.75.

598
00:28:00.819 --> 00:28:02.375
And that's the lowest they can go.

599
00:28:02.375 --> 00:28:05.155
They can't go any lower cuz it
won't be enough for Windows to run.

600
00:28:05.155 --> 00:28:08.230
For Linux, you could go lower,
but I don't think Microsoft does.

601
00:28:08.230 --> 00:28:10.310
But after that,
that's why these numbers are offset.

602
00:28:10.310 --> 00:28:11.990
It's the base operating
system meeting those.

603
00:28:11.990 --> 00:28:13.730
>> Well, thanks for
being transparent there, Microsoft.

604
00:28:13.730 --> 00:28:14.640
>> Eh, they're trying.

605
00:28:14.640 --> 00:28:15.567
>> We appreciate the honesty.

606
00:28:15.567 --> 00:28:16.990
[LAUGH]
>> Don,

607
00:28:16.990 --> 00:28:20.870
is there any other considerations that
we need to take in as a factor before we

608
00:28:20.870 --> 00:28:23.610
dive into Azure as
a virtual machine solution?

609
00:28:23.610 --> 00:28:27.010
>> Yeah, if you're talking to your CIO,
your CTO,

610
00:28:27.010 --> 00:28:30.460
whoever it is,
it's easy to fixate on these costs.

611
00:28:30.460 --> 00:28:32.660
And then you do what I did a moment ago,
and you say well,

612
00:28:32.660 --> 00:28:37.290
if a server costs me $8,000 but
I'm paying $72 a month,

613
00:28:37.290 --> 00:28:41.570
at some point, there has to be
a break-even price or whatever.

614
00:28:41.570 --> 00:28:44.760
It's really easy to fall into
that habit of comparing this

615
00:28:44.760 --> 00:28:47.650
per hour price to what
the actual server would cost.

616
00:28:47.650 --> 00:28:51.110
But understand that when you buy a server,
you're not just buying a server.

617
00:28:51.110 --> 00:28:52.580
There's more to it.

618
00:28:52.580 --> 00:28:54.960
There's the electricity
to keep it running.

619
00:28:54.960 --> 00:28:58.580
There's the battery backups to keep
it up during the power failure.

620
00:28:58.580 --> 00:29:00.190
There's the network bandwidth.

621
00:29:00.190 --> 00:29:02.578
There's redundant network connections,

622
00:29:02.578 --> 00:29:05.680
redundant fiber connections
to a storage area network.

623
00:29:05.680 --> 00:29:08.500
If it has virtualization,
there's the host OS and the guest OS.

624
00:29:08.500 --> 00:29:13.258
There's just the maintenance,
the software licensing, there's all

625
00:29:13.258 --> 00:29:18.350
sorts of other things that go along with
the cost of owning a physical server.

626
00:29:18.350 --> 00:29:22.100
Even with the physical server, when you
pay that, let's say it's $8,000 and

627
00:29:22.100 --> 00:29:25.360
you buy it on day one, well,
the next year rolls around, and

628
00:29:25.360 --> 00:29:28.520
you gotta re-up the warranty, or
maybe you get a three year warranty and

629
00:29:28.520 --> 00:29:30.140
you need to go to four or five years.

630
00:29:30.140 --> 00:29:32.800
Those are all unsaid costs.

631
00:29:32.800 --> 00:29:35.350
Costs that aren't in the base
price of that server.

632
00:29:35.350 --> 00:29:38.620
Those unsaid costs are a part of this.

633
00:29:38.620 --> 00:29:41.440
Microsoft already has battery
backups on all these servers.

634
00:29:41.440 --> 00:29:45.060
They already have redundant generators
to keep them on in a power failure.

635
00:29:45.060 --> 00:29:47.690
They've already gotten more
than one Internet connection.

636
00:29:47.690 --> 00:29:52.120
If a hard drive fails, it's not you, it's
a Microsoft tech who runs over there and

637
00:29:52.120 --> 00:29:54.080
pops that drive out and puts in a new one.

638
00:29:54.080 --> 00:29:57.590
It's a Microsoft tech that sees
there's a problem with your server and

639
00:29:57.590 --> 00:29:59.610
moves your virtual
machine to another host.

640
00:29:59.610 --> 00:30:03.390
So you're getting employees,
you're getting hardware, you're getting

641
00:30:03.390 --> 00:30:08.960
maintenance, monitoring, all these other
things for that small hourly price.

642
00:30:08.960 --> 00:30:12.670
And when you look at it that way,
the Azure cloud is so

643
00:30:12.670 --> 00:30:18.250
much less expensive than owning physical
servers that it's hard not to do it.

644
00:30:18.250 --> 00:30:21.450
In fact, there's really only a few
scenarios I can think of where you

645
00:30:21.450 --> 00:30:22.670
wouldn't want to go to a cloud.

646
00:30:23.740 --> 00:30:25.970
One example, data privacy.

647
00:30:25.970 --> 00:30:27.886
If you have a regulation, a law,

648
00:30:27.886 --> 00:30:31.379
something that says your data
has to be completely private,

649
00:30:31.379 --> 00:30:36.187
you might not trust the Azure cloud, you
might not trust the Microsoft employees.

650
00:30:36.187 --> 00:30:39.278
Now they are certified in a number
of different regulatory and

651
00:30:39.278 --> 00:30:42.670
compliance standards, so
they've got most of it covered.

652
00:30:42.670 --> 00:30:45.050
But there's still some environments
where you just can't use this, so

653
00:30:45.050 --> 00:30:46.540
that might be one scenario.

654
00:30:46.540 --> 00:30:50.080
Another scenario might be that
you need specialized hardware.

655
00:30:50.080 --> 00:30:53.880
Daniel and I, we used to work together at
an insurance company years and years back.

656
00:30:53.880 --> 00:30:55.250
And at that company,

657
00:30:55.250 --> 00:30:58.190
we had a fax server which,
do you remember the fax server, Dan?

658
00:30:58.190 --> 00:30:59.850
>> Oh, I remember the fax server.

659
00:30:59.850 --> 00:31:01.477
>> It was a ray of sunshine, wasn't it?

660
00:31:01.477 --> 00:31:02.150
>> It completely was.

661
00:31:02.150 --> 00:31:04.348
[LAUGH]
>> The thing about the fax server is

662
00:31:04.348 --> 00:31:08.012
it had this special modem board in
it that had, is it 8 or 16 ports,

663
00:31:08.012 --> 00:31:11.697
something crazy on there, so
that we could receive all these faxes.

664
00:31:11.697 --> 00:31:13.650
Well, I can't virtualize that system.

665
00:31:13.650 --> 00:31:15.970
I need that fax board,
I can't put that in Azure.

666
00:31:15.970 --> 00:31:18.770
I'm gonna have to have a physical server
for that, there's no way around it.

667
00:31:18.770 --> 00:31:23.355
So there are scenarios where Azure doesn't
work, but pricing isn't one of them.

668
00:31:23.355 --> 00:31:27.781
Azure always ends up being cheaper than
your physical server unless you do really

669
00:31:27.781 --> 00:31:32.153
like white box, build your own,
off the shelf, non-name brand type server.

670
00:31:32.153 --> 00:31:34.925
But then you have a higher
mean time between failure, and

671
00:31:34.925 --> 00:31:38.300
you end up losing all that savings
on the support side on the back end.

672
00:31:38.300 --> 00:31:41.825
We've all done it, we've all kind
of worked in that environment, and

673
00:31:41.825 --> 00:31:44.486
it's nice having Microsoft
worry about that for us.

674
00:31:44.486 --> 00:31:48.000
>> Yeah, when you buy a server,
it's not just buying a box.

675
00:31:48.000 --> 00:31:50.740
It's a lot of things
that go along with that.

676
00:31:50.740 --> 00:31:54.670
You gotta pay a guy like me or Don here or
maybe yourself, to make sure it's running,

677
00:31:54.670 --> 00:31:55.670
it's doing everything.

678
00:31:55.670 --> 00:31:58.280
When we go into the cloud,
that all gets pushed off.

679
00:31:58.280 --> 00:32:02.032
We get to be freed up to do more important
things, developing infrastructure,

680
00:32:02.032 --> 00:32:03.320
working support tickets,

681
00:32:03.320 --> 00:32:06.970
things that are much more important
than swapping out hard drives and stuff.

682
00:32:06.970 --> 00:32:07.620
So Don,

683
00:32:07.620 --> 00:32:11.130
is there anything else we need to cover
in this show before we close it down?

684
00:32:11.130 --> 00:32:12.350
>> That's it for the basics.

685
00:32:12.350 --> 00:32:16.140
We're gonna move on to talking about
actually creating the VMs, and

686
00:32:16.140 --> 00:32:19.850
I know I showed some information up here
that I didn't explain in great detail.

687
00:32:19.850 --> 00:32:21.670
We're gonna see that in
the upcoming episodes.

688
00:32:21.670 --> 00:32:23.220
So we got a lot more to go into.

689
00:32:23.220 --> 00:32:25.690
But I just wanted to make sure I started
off with the basics of Azure for

690
00:32:25.690 --> 00:32:28.430
those of you that haven't used it or
aren't familiar with it.

691
00:32:28.430 --> 00:32:30.207
It really is a great system,
you'll enjoy it.

692
00:32:30.207 --> 00:32:31.213
It's pretty easy to use and

693
00:32:31.213 --> 00:32:34.294
definitely something you'll wanna take
advantage of out there in the real world.

694
00:32:34.294 --> 00:32:35.900
>> That's right, excellent stuff, Don.

695
00:32:35.900 --> 00:32:37.090
Thanks for joining us today.

696
00:32:37.090 --> 00:32:39.710
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

697
00:32:39.710 --> 00:32:40.938
I've been your host, Daniel Lowery.

698
00:32:40.938 --> 00:32:41.693
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

699
00:32:41.693 --> 00:32:42.597
>> And we'll see you next time.

700
00:32:42.597 --> 00:32:47.783
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore some of the default limits to the Azure Virtual Machines. This includes the default CPU core limits, DNS restrictions, and storage sizes. Then they explain how to push beyond those limits when the need arises. Finally, they explain the differences in Azure VM types. This covers the Basic vs. Standard tiers as well as the A, D/DS, and G/GS series of Virtual Machines.
episodes.title: Virtual Machine Types
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.246 --> 00:00:10.246
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.007 --> 00:00:16.830
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.830 --> 00:00:21.430
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in this
episode we're gonna keep taking a look at

4
00:00:21.430 --> 00:00:25.810
the Microsoft Azure Virtual machines that
are available from, well, Microsoft.

5
00:00:25.810 --> 00:00:28.870
And who better to help us out with this,
is none other than my good friend,

6
00:00:28.870 --> 00:00:30.740
my colleague, Mr. Don Pezet.

7
00:00:30.740 --> 00:00:32.230
Welcome to the show, Don.

8
00:00:32.230 --> 00:00:33.520
>> Thank you.
Thank you for having me, Daniel.

9
00:00:33.520 --> 00:00:36.350
Glad to be back on the show and
ready to talk more about virtual machines.

10
00:00:36.350 --> 00:00:40.810
We did a great job in the first
episode talking about Azure.

11
00:00:40.810 --> 00:00:43.220
And completely failing to
deploy any virtual machines.

12
00:00:43.220 --> 00:00:48.180
So, in this episode, I want to follow up
that amazing performance by talking about

13
00:00:48.180 --> 00:00:52.350
the different considerations we have to
have before we actually implement a VM.

14
00:00:52.350 --> 00:00:55.720
And I imagine we'll totally fail to
deploy any VMs this episode, too, but

15
00:00:55.720 --> 00:00:59.190
there is a lot we need to be aware
of before we even get started.

16
00:00:59.190 --> 00:01:01.260
And even some of the information
I showed in the last episode,

17
00:01:01.260 --> 00:01:04.117
we need to revisit and
go a little more in-depth on.

18
00:01:04.117 --> 00:01:08.020
So, I want to talk about the different
types of hardware that we end up with.

19
00:01:08.020 --> 00:01:11.670
The different ways of implementing
things and the different, in general,

20
00:01:11.670 --> 00:01:15.480
considerations we need to have before we
start rolling out VMs in the network.

21
00:01:15.480 --> 00:01:16.590
>> Now that being said, Don.

22
00:01:16.590 --> 00:01:22.040
The word on the street is that these Azure
VMs, well, they have some limitations.

23
00:01:22.040 --> 00:01:25.040
They're not Almighty,
omnipotent obnisions?,

24
00:01:25.040 --> 00:01:28.790
they do have some boundaries per say.

25
00:01:28.790 --> 00:01:30.230
I guess it would be a good idea for

26
00:01:30.230 --> 00:01:33.070
us if we're going to get
into the cloud solutions,

27
00:01:33.070 --> 00:01:37.190
like Azure, to know what the boundaries
are and where those limitations lie.

28
00:01:37.190 --> 00:01:39.870
>> Yeah whenever you
create an Azure account

29
00:01:39.870 --> 00:01:44.360
they ask you to fill out the forms, submit
your credit card, you're basically buying

30
00:01:44.360 --> 00:01:47.640
a subscription to Azure
>> And as part of your subscription

31
00:01:47.640 --> 00:01:51.990
there are certain limits that are in
place that aren't immediately obvious.

32
00:01:51.990 --> 00:01:56.600
And what they do is they create these
limits to protect your account.

33
00:01:56.600 --> 00:01:57.130
Right?

34
00:01:57.130 --> 00:01:59.100
Imagine and here's what happens.

35
00:01:59.100 --> 00:02:01.390
Imagine your username and
your password get out somehow.

36
00:02:01.390 --> 00:02:04.900
Somebody guesses it, or
they run a keylogger on your machine.

37
00:02:04.900 --> 00:02:06.790
Somebody could connect your account.

38
00:02:06.790 --> 00:02:12.440
They can spin up 10,000 virtual machines
and start BitCoin mining on your system

39
00:02:12.440 --> 00:02:17.180
and run for hours, days, maybe even weeks
before you notice how high your bill is.

40
00:02:17.180 --> 00:02:20.610
Right, that's the risk we have with
something like a cloud service like this.

41
00:02:20.610 --> 00:02:22.360
Your account is very sensitive.

42
00:02:22.360 --> 00:02:25.760
So when you sign up a new Azure account,
Microsoft

43
00:02:25.760 --> 00:02:29.020
puts certain restrictions on there to
protect you from that exact scenario.

44
00:02:29.020 --> 00:02:30.970
So that if somebody broke
into your account and

45
00:02:30.970 --> 00:02:35.350
really started to ramp up utilization,
well, they would be able to,

46
00:02:35.350 --> 00:02:37.960
they'd hit that ceiling,
hit that and stop.

47
00:02:37.960 --> 00:02:40.990
When this really becomes a problem is that
some people don't know about the limits.

48
00:02:40.990 --> 00:02:43.370
And so they say, all right I've
got 200 servers in my data center,

49
00:02:43.370 --> 00:02:48.210
I wanna roll them out and, oh shoot,
it stopped after just 20 virtual machines.

50
00:02:48.210 --> 00:02:49.050
What's going on there?

51
00:02:49.050 --> 00:02:51.010
Right, and that happens.

52
00:02:51.010 --> 00:02:54.460
It's part of the process unfortunately,
part of the learning curve.

53
00:02:54.460 --> 00:02:57.090
So before we get in,
let's talk about those limits.

54
00:02:57.090 --> 00:03:00.410
First of I said 20 hours,
I wasn't making that number up.

55
00:03:00.410 --> 00:03:01.830
That's a real number.

56
00:03:01.830 --> 00:03:03.255
You're limited to 20 cores.

57
00:03:03.255 --> 00:03:04.409
You have what's called a core quota.

58
00:03:04.409 --> 00:03:07.500
And your core quota is set to 20 by
default, and it's 20 per region.

59
00:03:07.500 --> 00:03:10.970
So if I go into the US East region and

60
00:03:10.970 --> 00:03:16.030
I spin up 20 single-core virtual machines,
I'm at my limit.

61
00:03:16.030 --> 00:03:18.730
If I try to do one more, then I can't.

62
00:03:18.730 --> 00:03:20.390
And it won't let me spin it up.

63
00:03:20.390 --> 00:03:21.810
If I spin up five.

64

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don show you how to create a Microsoft Azure Virtual Machine. episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain how to install and configure PowerShell for Azure. episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don walk you through connecting to an Azure Virtual Machine. They start by explaining the default access methods for connecting to both a Windows Server VM (Remote Desktop) and a Linux VM (SSH). Then they explain how to add security to those access methods using the Azure Firewall.
episodes.title: Connecting to a VM

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore how to use Azure to quickly deploy a custom virtual machine "image". episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don walk you through creating custom scripts in PowerShell, to automate custom deployments in Azure. 00:03:16.880 --> 00:03:19.950

67

69
00:03:33.430 --> 00:03:34.010
And that's great.

70
00:03:34.010 --> 00:03:35.990

you boot off the disc.

71
00:03:35.990 --> 00:03:38.040

00:03:38.040 --> 00:03:39.400
So we got two choices.

Choice number one is I can do an image.

00:03:55.210 --> 00:03:57.430

79

If I need a web server right now

80
00:04:00.860 --> 00:04:03.670

gonna have to do it manually.

81
00:04:03.670 --> 00:04:05.440
Well, not if I script it.

00:04:05.440 --> 00:04:07.520
Right?
And then the other problem is,

00:04:07.520 --> 00:04:09.690

let's say it's a web server and

00:04:09.690 --> 00:04:13.610

00:04:13.610 --> 00:04:15.660
Now my website's in the image.

00:04:15.660 --> 00:04:17.890

00:04:17.890 --> 00:04:20.440
Now, I've gotta go and
update the image also.

88
00:04:20.440 --> 00:04:22.610
And that's a little bit of
a weakness there with that image.

00:04:22.610 --> 00:04:26.150
And so any time I spin up a new

00:04:26.150 --> 00:04:28.410

00:04:28.410 --> 00:04:32.740

00:04:32.740 --> 00:04:34.320

to happen automatically right.

97
00:04:46.000 --> 00:04:48.160
Well it's actually a pretty
straight forward process.

98
00:04:48.160 --> 00:04:49.440
Let me show you here in the Azure portal.

99
00:04:49.440 --> 00:04:53.260
So I'm logged into the new portal and
I'm just gonna go into virtual machines.

100
00:04:53.260 --> 00:04:56.340
Now I'll do a classic virtual machine,
I'm not going to go crazy with this.

101
00:04:56.340 --> 00:04:59.160
And I'll just add in a new
virtual machine here and

102

when I go to add it in, it's gonna ask

103
00:05:03.220 --> 00:05:06.418
And I'm just gonna choose
a standard Windows Server and

00:05:06.418 --> 00:05:10.717
when it asks which kind,

105
00:05:10.717 --> 00:05:12.344
Actually we want R2 data center.

106
00:05:12.344 --> 00:05:14.257
There we go.

107
00:05:14.257 --> 00:05:16.180
What I'm gonna do, it doesn't really
matter if it's R2 or not, but

108

as we move around the other stamps as we
get sent from one data center to another.

00:22:32.090 --> 00:22:35.530
This data gets preserved and it sticks
with us and that's what's important.

00:22:35.530 --> 00:22:37.510
These are what we need to use.

00:22:44.230 --> 00:22:44.730

00:22:44.730 --> 00:22:47.770

So am I not paying for 500 gigs?

00:22:56.410 --> 00:22:57.360
Well, actually, you're not.

470
00:22:57.360 --> 00:22:59.700
It's gonna be an interesting thing
that goes on behind the scenes here.

471
00:22:59.700 --> 00:23:03.900
In Hyper V, you have dynamic disks,
and you have fixed disks.

472
00:23:03.900 --> 00:23:04.980
With a fixed disk,

473
00:23:04.980 --> 00:23:10.490
if I set it on a 500 gig disk, it sets
out 500 gigs from that very moment.

474
00:23:10.490 --> 00:23:13.550
If I do a dynamic disk,
when I create a 500 gig disk,

475
00:23:13.550 --> 00:23:15.620
it actually creates a very small file.

476
00:23:15.620 --> 00:23:18.340
And I as copy data into it,
it starts to grow and grow and

477
00:23:18.340 --> 00:23:19.960
grow to reflect the amount
of data that's in there.

478
00:23:19.960 --> 00:23:23.480
Now, that's cool from
a money saving perspective.

479
00:23:23.480 --> 00:23:26.350
It's not so
cool from a performance perspective.

480
00:23:26.350 --> 00:23:29.600
As a dynamic disk grows,
it hurts your disk I/O.

481
00:23:29.600 --> 00:23:33.950
And Microsoft wants to guarantee a certain
level of service with disk I/O, and so

482
00:23:33.950 --> 00:23:35.020
they don't use dynamic discs.

483
00:23:35.020 --> 00:23:37.250
They only use fixed discs.

484
00:23:37.250 --> 00:23:39.910
But at the same time,
they don't want you to have to pay for

485
00:23:39.910 --> 00:23:41.300
storage you're not using.

486
00:23:41.300 --> 00:23:43.070
And so when they provision this disk,

487
00:23:43.070 --> 00:23:46.380
on the back end it's something
special called a sparse disk.

488
00:23:46.380 --> 00:23:50.601
And a sparse disk is where it lays out
the 500 gigs, it knows it's that size,

489
00:23:50.601 --> 00:23:52.183
it's kinda got it reserved.

490
00:23:52.183 --> 00:23:55.641
But you only get billed for
the space that you're actually using.

00:23:55.641 --> 00:24:00.409

00:25:01.600 --> 00:25:04.170
It only creates the the partition
table at the beginning to make

00:25:04.170 --> 00:25:05.100
sure that it's erased.

00:25:05.100 --> 00:25:06.220
That's what you want.

00:25:06.220 --> 00:25:08.420
Okay, it's going to leave
the rest of the drive alone and

00:25:08.420 --> 00:25:10.530

00:25:10.530 --> 00:25:14.640
You'll get the performance of a fixed

00:25:14.640 --> 00:25:16.480
You get all the benefits, right?

If you do a quick format.

It's gonna write a zero to every sector.

00:25:27.900 --> 00:25:29.860

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue to explore storage management in Microsoft Azure Virtual Machines. Picking up where they left off, they add a disk to a VM using Azure PowerShell and then connect a pre-existing disk to a VM. Next they explain the different Storage Account types like L(Locally Redudndant), G(Geo Redundant), R(Read-Access Geo Redundant), P(Premium Locally Redundant), and Z(Zone Redundant). Finally, they cover monitoring your disk performance and setting up alerts.

00:25:06.980 --> 00:25:09.605
Now, locally redundant
is still pretty good.

505
00:25:09.605 --> 00:25:13.965
Inside of a region,
each stamp is completely independent.

506
00:25:13.965 --> 00:25:16.655
It's got its own Internet connection,
its own power, its own generators,

507
00:25:16.655 --> 00:25:19.315
its own UPS,
own network operations center.

508
00:25:19.315 --> 00:25:20.615
It's got own everything.

509
00:25:20.615 --> 00:25:22.505
Each little stamp is independent.

510
00:25:22.505 --> 00:25:27.655
So if a stamp fails, I'm redundant to
another stamp in that same region,

511
00:25:27.655 --> 00:25:29.700
and that's good enough for most people.

512
00:25:29.700 --> 00:25:33.680
But if a whole region were to fail,
that's where geo-redundant comes in.

513
00:25:33.680 --> 00:25:38.810
Well, geo-redundant is storing more copies
and so, my head's actually covering it up,

514
00:25:38.810 --> 00:25:42.380
but down here you can see
where it's $2.40 for 100 gigs.

515
00:25:42.380 --> 00:25:44.190
Normally it's $4.80 for 100 gigs.

516
00:25:44.190 --> 00:25:46.970
And this one is twice the cost.

517
00:25:46.970 --> 00:25:49.298
You store twice the copies,
it's twice the cost.

518
00:25:49.298 --> 00:25:51.700
That makes sense.

519
00:25:51.700 --> 00:25:55.670
Now, one thing about the geo-redundant
copy is the distributed replica,

520
00:25:55.670 --> 00:25:56.590
you can't touch them.

521
00:25:56.590 --> 00:25:58.420
You're not allowed to use them.

522
00:25:58.420 --> 00:26:00.240
They exist,
you can see that they exist, but

523
00:26:00.240 --> 00:26:02.820
you're not allowed to touch them
unless you fail over to them.

524
00:26:02.820 --> 00:26:04.770
When you fail over,
then you can touch them.

525
00:26:04.770 --> 00:26:08.410
So while there are six copies,
you're really only working with three.

526
00:26:08.410 --> 00:26:11.580
And you write synchronously
to these three, but

527
00:26:11.580 --> 00:26:14.050
you write asynchronous to these three.

528
00:26:14.050 --> 00:26:15.540
To the remotes, right?

529
00:26:15.540 --> 00:26:19.230
It doesn't want to hold up your rights
in your main data center while it's

530
00:26:19.230 --> 00:26:21.900
waiting to write somewhere
else on the globe.

531
00:26:21.900 --> 00:26:23.560
So it will speed those up.

532
00:26:23.560 --> 00:26:27.980
But it does cost more, if you want
to take advantage of those replicas.

533
00:26:27.980 --> 00:26:31.790
They do support,
let's see it's buried somewhere down here,

534
00:26:31.790 --> 00:26:35.190
what's called a read access GO replica.

535
00:26:35.190 --> 00:26:36.270
This guy right here in r.

536
00:26:36.270 --> 00:26:40.430
And with these guys you still have
the three and three, right, but

537
00:26:40.430 --> 00:26:44.410
If not,
you can actually read from your replicas.

538
00:26:44.410 --> 00:26:47.450
So if you got a database stuck out
there you could be running reports

539
00:26:47.450 --> 00:26:48.710
off of that read only copy.

540
00:26:48.710 --> 00:26:51.900
Or you could be taking your backups
off that read only copy and

541
00:26:51.900 --> 00:26:54.000
not effecting your production data.

542
00:26:54.000 --> 00:26:56.310
Backups actually occur
off of a replica already,

543
00:26:56.310 --> 00:26:58.120
it's just one of the local replicas.

544
00:26:58.120 --> 00:27:01.950
So these let you back it up from
a completely geo located replica.

545
00:27:01.950 --> 00:27:04.055
So you got that option,
but there is a cost to it.

546
00:27:04.055 --> 00:27:06.610
$6.10 per 100 gigs.

547
00:27:06.610 --> 00:27:09.600
So we went from $2.40 to $4.80,
now we go to $6.10, so

548
00:27:09.600 --> 00:27:14.860
we're almost three times the cost of
the LRS that we normally have, the local.

549
00:27:16.100 --> 00:27:20.310
Then there's two special kinds.

550
00:27:20.310 --> 00:27:26.750
The special replication types,
we've got zone redundant.

551
00:27:26.750 --> 00:27:31.610
Zone redundant is kind of in between L and
G.

552
00:27:31.610 --> 00:27:32.690
L was local.

553
00:27:32.690 --> 00:27:36.170
Where we had three copies stored
right here in our data center.

554
00:27:36.170 --> 00:27:38.980
And then, let's see, that was this one, L.

555
00:27:38.980 --> 00:27:40.850
And then G was where we had six copies.

556
00:27:40.850 --> 00:27:43.190
Three in our data center,
three somewhere else.

557
00:27:43.190 --> 00:27:47.010
Zone redundant is where
we have three copies

558
00:27:47.010 --> 00:27:49.350
in multiple zones in the data center.

559
00:27:49.350 --> 00:27:53.150
So in the data center Microsoft
has it divided up by these stamps,

560
00:27:53.150 --> 00:27:56.560
these independent areas and it makes
sure that we're redundant across those.

561
00:27:56.560 --> 00:27:58.210
Now normally we already are.

562
00:27:58.210 --> 00:28:00.820
We've already got one copy of
this in one of these other areas.

563
00:28:00.820 --> 00:28:04.350
Here they make sure that all three
copies are spread out that way.

564
00:28:04.350 --> 00:28:08.830
And so what's why, if you look at the cost
of that, it's not that much higher.

565
00:28:08.830 --> 00:28:12.820
The cost on it is only $3.00 versus $2.40,
now we're $3.00 not much more cuz it's not

566
00:28:12.820 --> 00:28:17.380
really that much more redundancy, we're
already getting some of that redundancy.

567
00:28:17.380 --> 00:28:20.580
But notice this,
it's only supported for block and blob.

568
00:28:20.580 --> 00:28:22.560
It doesn't work for table and queue.

569
00:28:22.560 --> 00:28:25.920
Well, VHDs are stored as block blobs.

570
00:28:25.920 --> 00:28:29.380
So that works for VHDs, doesn't work for
some of the other stuff.

571
00:28:29.380 --> 00:28:31.270
This is one of the probably
least used though.

572
00:28:32.930 --> 00:28:37.550
The only other one that I
haven't talked about is P.

573
00:28:37.550 --> 00:28:40.490
And P is the premium locally redundant.

574
00:28:40.490 --> 00:28:45.830
It's still locally redundant, just like L,
but the difference is the IOs.

575
00:28:45.830 --> 00:28:50.420
In a normal storage account, you've
got a max of 5 hundred IOPS per disk.

576
00:28:50.420 --> 00:28:53.813
In a premium it's 5,000.

577
00:28:53.813 --> 00:28:57.800
You get 10 times the IOs on a premium.

578
00:28:57.800 --> 00:29:01.900
And so if I'm trying to get the best
disk performance, I want one of those.

579
00:29:01.900 --> 00:29:06.980
So when I create a storage account,
I pick between these 5 tiers, which

580
00:29:06.980 --> 00:29:10.420
one I want based on my needs, and based
on the amount of money I wanna spend.

581
00:29:10.420 --> 00:29:13.680
And then when I create a blank VHD,
or when I upload a VHD,

582
00:29:13.680 --> 00:29:18.180
when I send it into that storage account
it's gonna take on these properties.

583
00:29:18.180 --> 00:29:23.890
So if we upload Daniels VHD, and I upload
it into a storage account that was set for

584
00:29:23.890 --> 00:29:26.480
a premium,
it's gonna get three copies made,

585
00:29:26.480 --> 00:29:31.270
and I'm gonna have 5,000 IOPS's on it,
and it's gonna scream, right?

586
00:29:31.270 --> 00:29:34.510
Or if I upload it into a G,
then it's gonna have that characteristic

587
00:29:34.510 --> 00:29:39.190
of being stored in two different regions,
three copies each, six copies total.

588
00:29:39.190 --> 00:29:40.270
We have to pick.

589
00:29:40.270 --> 00:29:42.220
Notice that premium It's $17.92.

590
00:29:42.220 --> 00:29:46.780
It's significantly more expensive
than any of the others,

591
00:29:46.780 --> 00:29:50.740
cuz you're getting ten
times the disk access.

592
00:29:50.740 --> 00:29:52.050
>> It's a very nice feature, though.

593
00:29:52.050 --> 00:29:54.000
It's gonna depend on what
environment you're in.

594
00:29:54.000 --> 00:29:56.050
You gotta figure out what
you're gonna go with.

595
00:29:56.050 --> 00:29:57.640
So you really gotta try to break it down.

596
00:29:57.640 --> 00:30:00.650
Look at each one of the different
tiers that they have.

597
00:30:00.650 --> 00:30:03.600
And try to figure out which one
is gonna work best for you.

598
00:30:03.600 --> 00:30:05.960
Now speaking of trying to figure out
which one is gonna work best for

599
00:30:05.960 --> 00:30:09.620
us, we're looking at those IOPS,
those disk input/output.

600
00:30:09.620 --> 00:30:10.870
It's a very important thing.

601
00:30:10.870 --> 00:30:12.620
We're talking about storage here.

602
00:30:12.620 --> 00:30:17.570
And in this day and age of doing
things like super big databases or

603
00:30:17.570 --> 00:30:21.200
video rendering, that kind of stuff,
how do I know that I'm getting that, Don?

604
00:30:21.200 --> 00:30:23.200
That's really the question is.

605
00:30:23.200 --> 00:30:26.170
How do I know if need
a 500 versus a 5,000?

606
00:30:26.170 --> 00:30:29.480
What is there that's gonna
allow me to see that and

607
00:30:29.480 --> 00:30:31.440
then make my decision accordingly?

608
00:30:31.440 --> 00:30:35.650
>> Some people, like database admins, if
you go to them they make it their job to

609
00:30:35.650 --> 00:30:38.340
know how many IOs they're generating,
it's really important.

610
00:30:38.340 --> 00:30:41.370
But that's not something you
deal with My recommendation is,

611
00:30:41.370 --> 00:30:43.460
don't start with the premiums,
start with the low end.

612
00:30:43.460 --> 00:30:46.320
Because what you can do, is you can
monitor for when you're being throttled.

613
00:30:46.320 --> 00:30:48.730
When you hit your limit you get
throttled back and you can monitor for

614
00:30:48.730 --> 00:30:51.970
when that happens, and that will tell you
you need to step up to the next level.

615
00:30:51.970 --> 00:30:53.720
And it's actually not
that hard to monitor.

616
00:30:53.720 --> 00:30:56.770
If we want to do it,
all we have to do is go into our UI,

617
00:30:56.770 --> 00:31:01.810
go into your storage account, let me just
go back to my storage accounts here.

618
00:31:03.210 --> 00:31:09.040
And I'll pick maybe my ITProTV demo
account that we've got from before.

619
00:31:10.080 --> 00:31:12.180
I'm just gonna discard
creating that new one.

620
00:31:12.180 --> 00:31:13.780
So I'm gonna pick this guy.

621
00:31:13.780 --> 00:31:17.250
It's really wanting me to be aware
of me discarding those changes.

622
00:31:17.250 --> 00:31:19.460
So I'm gonna go into my
ITProTV demo storage, and

623
00:31:19.460 --> 00:31:21.380
so here I can see the account
that I've already got.

624
00:31:21.380 --> 00:31:25.690
It's in East US 2, it's available,
I've already got some data in here.

625
00:31:25.690 --> 00:31:29.310
And on the right side,
as I go into my settings over here,

626
00:31:29.310 --> 00:31:32.720
what I'll see is I've
got a monitor section.

627
00:31:32.720 --> 00:31:36.290
And I can create alert rules,
audit logs and diagnostics.

628
00:31:36.290 --> 00:31:39.854
Under alerts rules,
I can create a rule that monitors for

629
00:31:39.854 --> 00:31:42.536
when I'm being throttled it notifies me.

630
00:31:42.536 --> 00:31:47.097
And so I can turn this on, and if I never
get an alert, I can just stay at 500 IOs,

631
00:31:47.097 --> 00:31:47.970
I'll be fine.

632
00:31:47.970 --> 00:31:50.499
But if it starts to hit alerts a lot,
then I know, eh,

00:31:50.499 --> 00:31:52.032
maybe I need to step this one up.

634
00:31:52.032 --> 00:31:56.644
And I could move it to premium storage or
I could add a second data disc,

635
00:31:56.644 --> 00:32:00.645
bond them together and
double my IOs on that system, right?

636
00:32:00.645 --> 00:32:03.501
So there's different ways to solve that,
and we'll show that in another episode.

637
00:32:03.501 --> 00:32:07.758
But I'm gonna go in here to Alert rules
and you'll see I haven't created any,

638
00:32:07.758 --> 00:32:09.850
so I've got no alert rules yet.

639
00:32:09.850 --> 00:32:11.820
I'll choose to add an alert rule.

640
00:32:11.820 --> 00:32:16.240
And now, it's gonna start asking me some
of the settings for this particular alert.

641
00:32:16.240 --> 00:32:18.760
So, it's gonna ask what I'm monitoring.

642
00:32:18.760 --> 00:32:22.180
And I went into itprotvdemostorage, that's
what it's already got chosen for me.

643
00:32:22.180 --> 00:32:23.520
I can give it an alert.

644
00:32:23.520 --> 00:32:28.674
I'll call it IOPS Throttling.

00:32:28.674 --> 00:32:32.700
I can give it a Description if I care for

00:32:32.700 --> 00:32:36.030
And in my Metric list,
there's a lot of stuff in here.

00:32:36.030 --> 00:32:39.860
And the one that I'm looking for

648
00:32:39.860 --> 00:32:42.930
There it is, ThrottlingError, okay?

649
00:32:42.930 --> 00:32:45.160
I'm gonna monitor for
that ThrottlingError.

00:32:45.160 --> 00:32:48.210
So when the system generates
a ThrottlingError where I hit my limit,

00:32:48.210 --> 00:32:49.730
I want it to notify me.

00:32:49.730 --> 00:32:51.760

00:32:52.830 --> 00:32:54.700
And then when I create that error,

00:33:00.950 --> 00:33:03.760
which you can see mine's

00:33:03.760 --> 00:33:07.818
I haven't hit my limit.

00:33:07.818 --> 00:33:11.917
So I'll say if the Threshold is 1,
for a period of, and

00:33:11.917 --> 00:33:14.284
then I just need to say how long.

00:33:14.284 --> 00:33:18.620
So if I'm exceeding that for greater
than an hour, I want to know about it.

661
00:33:18.620 --> 00:33:24.070
And I can say email the admins, or I can
specify a particular person to email.

662
00:33:24.070 --> 00:33:26.330
And now it'll let us know if
we hit that throttling error.

663
00:33:26.330 --> 00:33:27.070
And I can say, OK.

664
00:33:27.070 --> 00:33:28.170
It's gonna whip that up.

665
00:33:28.170 --> 00:33:31.270
And now I've got an alert created.

666
00:33:31.270 --> 00:33:34.350
And I'm monitoring for
any IOPS throttling.

667
00:33:34.350 --> 00:33:38.300
So that's kinda cool because
I can start with a 500 and

00:33:38.300 --> 00:33:41.410
maybe that turns out to be fine and
I don't need to pay the extra money.

669
00:33:41.410 --> 00:33:44.337

I can add one disk, and

00:33:45.977 --> 00:33:48.467

00:33:54.020 --> 00:33:56.111

00:33:57.634 --> 00:34:01.315

00:34:04.482 --> 00:34:06.667

00:34:11.162 --> 00:34:14.267

00:34:19.724 --> 00:34:22.521

00:34:25.412 --> 00:34:28.480

00:34:28.480 --> 00:34:32.220

00:34:32.220 --> 00:34:34.460

00:34:34.460 --> 00:34:35.940

00:34:35.940 --> 00:34:39.150

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel explain the concept and application of storage pools with Azure Virtual Machines. They start by creating a storage pool in a Windows environment using Storage Services. Then they jump over into a Linux VM and show you how partition disks using fdisk and then use LVM to group disks together to create a Volume Group and a Logical Volume.

00:23:43.452 --> 00:23:46.430
you're able to control it on your end and
not have to rely on Microsoft do it.

469
00:23:46.430 --> 00:23:51.312
>> Yeah, I guess if I needed more than
those 500 I/Os, even though if I had

470
00:23:51.312 --> 00:23:56.136
that 1 TB of storage space that I needed,
out of adding that disk to my VM.

471
00:23:56.136 --> 00:23:57.611
I'm not getting the IOs that I need, so

472
00:23:57.611 --> 00:23:59.549
going this way would
definitely solve that issue.

473
00:23:59.549 --> 00:24:03.200
So this definitely has some
advantages to using this system.

474
00:24:03.200 --> 00:24:06.580
>> Yeah, and you know, let's take my
systems here where I've D1s spun up, so

475
00:24:06.580 --> 00:24:08.370
I can only have two more data disks.

476
00:24:08.370 --> 00:24:13.320
Well, if I want to add more,
I decide hey, I need 1200 IOs and

477
00:24:13.320 --> 00:24:15.810
so I need to go to three data disks for
that.

478
00:24:15.810 --> 00:24:17.860
Well I can't because I'm on a D1.

479
00:24:17.860 --> 00:24:21.770
So I might need to reprovision my VM and
go to a D2 or a D3 or

480
00:24:21.770 --> 00:24:24.350
something higher so I can get more disks.

481
00:24:24.350 --> 00:24:27.740
And you can do that right, when you reach
that point where you have that storage

482
00:24:27.740 --> 00:24:32.290
need, you can bump up to a D2,
bump up to something higher.

483
00:24:32.290 --> 00:24:36.520
And when you do, then you'll be able
to get to that next level on it.

484
00:24:36.520 --> 00:24:40.150
Now, just remember that
you can't really bump

485
00:24:40.150 --> 00:24:43.900
up between the hardware types
while the system is booted up.

486
00:24:43.900 --> 00:24:47.743
So you may need to stop your system and
shut it down and once it's shut down,

487
00:24:47.743 --> 00:24:50.820
you can go and try to change
over to that other data type.

488
00:24:50.820 --> 00:24:53.430
So there is down time that's involved.

489
00:24:53.430 --> 00:24:56.802
And it can take a little while for
machines to shut down sometimes, but

490
00:24:56.802 --> 00:24:59.380
I'll shut this one down and
once that's done.

491
00:24:59.380 --> 00:25:01.320
Right now, I'm at a standard DS.

492
00:25:01.320 --> 00:25:02.700
I picked a DS one.

493
00:25:02.700 --> 00:25:07.350
I'm on the faster SSD,
but I'm on a DS one here.

494
00:25:07.350 --> 00:25:11.810
And once that's done we can jump into our
settings for that machine and bump it up

495
00:25:11.810 --> 00:25:18.140
to another tier and start to get that
additional data access that we can get.

496
00:25:18.140 --> 00:25:19.490
So I'm on that virtual machine here.

497
00:25:19.490 --> 00:25:24.765
And on the right side I'm just
gonna try and go down to Size.

498
00:25:24.765 --> 00:25:29.330
[LAUGH] If I can get my mouse working,
I'll go to Size.

499
00:25:29.330 --> 00:25:34.810
And under Size, now I can switch
from DS1 to one of the other tiers.

500
00:25:34.810 --> 00:25:35.530
There we go.

501
00:25:35.530 --> 00:25:39.190
So I'm on a DS1 standard, and
see how it says two data disks, but

502
00:25:39.190 --> 00:25:41.480
a DS2 can have four data disks.

503
00:25:41.480 --> 00:25:46.100
And so I can step up to that DS2 and
select it, right?

504
00:25:46.100 --> 00:25:49.330
And it's gonna be more expensive but
I've got a need.

505
00:25:49.330 --> 00:25:52.920
I need more IO, otherwise my customer
experience is gonna be slow.

506
00:25:52.920 --> 00:25:54.650
So now I can bump it up to that DS2.

507
00:25:55.740 --> 00:26:01.350
And once it's up to that DS2,
eventually this will update to show it, or

508
00:26:01.350 --> 00:26:04.150
it's still taking effect,
still taking effect, so it's resizing it.

509
00:26:04.150 --> 00:26:05.850
Now that can take awhile.

510
00:26:05.850 --> 00:26:09.100
Sometimes it's really fast,
sometimes you do it and it's just done.

511
00:26:09.100 --> 00:26:14.030
If your server is already in a rack
that already has DS2 availability in it,

512
00:26:14.030 --> 00:26:15.910
it will happen almost instantly.

513
00:26:15.910 --> 00:26:18.730
But it could be that you happen to
be moved to a different rack which

514
00:26:18.730 --> 00:26:19.780
is not a big deal.

515
00:26:19.780 --> 00:26:22.440
Sometimes you have to be moved
to an entirely different stamp

516
00:26:22.440 --> 00:26:24.110
which is a big deal, right?

517
00:26:24.110 --> 00:26:28.160
So your stamp that you're in,
the 20 or 25 racks, might be full.

518
00:26:28.160 --> 00:26:29.290
Might not has DS2's.

519
00:26:29.290 --> 00:26:32.100
I might have picked a tier that it just
doesn't support in the rack and so

520
00:26:32.100 --> 00:26:34.920
then it's got to move me to a whole
different stamp and that can take a while.

521
00:26:34.920 --> 00:26:36.050
This one wasn't so bad.

522
00:26:36.050 --> 00:26:37.460
But, I can see that I am now a DS2.

523
00:26:37.460 --> 00:26:40.760
And if I start that up,
now it's gonna fire up and

524
00:26:40.760 --> 00:26:42.600
I can start to add more disks into it.

525
00:26:42.600 --> 00:26:46.230
And now I can get up to four data disks
and start to gain advantage there.

526
00:26:46.230 --> 00:26:49.210
Now, one other thing worth mentioning.

527
00:26:49.210 --> 00:26:50.860
Let's say you only need
a one terabyte drive.

528
00:26:52.020 --> 00:26:55.630
I might still do two 500 gig drives.

00:26:55.630 --> 00:26:57.820
Knowing that I could have just
done a one terabyte drive, but

530
00:26:57.820 --> 00:27:01.660
because I get the extra IOs, all right?

531
00:27:01.660 --> 00:27:05.470
Two 500 gig drives will cost you
the same as one terabyte drive,

532
00:27:05.470 --> 00:27:08.160
cuz you pay per gigabyte that you use,
right?

533
00:27:08.160 --> 00:27:10.620
So you might as well go ahead and
do two 500s.

534
00:27:10.620 --> 00:27:12.690
Or if you're doing 128s, right?

535
00:27:12.690 --> 00:27:15.000
You'd go ahead and
just do, what is it eight?

536
00:27:15.000 --> 00:27:17.480
128s to get to that terabyte,
this is my amazing math skills here.

537
00:27:17.480 --> 00:27:18.550
That's wrong isn't it?

538
00:27:18.550 --> 00:27:19.130
It's not eight.

539
00:27:19.130 --> 00:27:19.790
>> Eight 128s.
>> Whatever.

540
00:27:19.790 --> 00:27:22.278
>> It was close, somewhere around there.

541
00:27:22.278 --> 00:27:26.420
>> So anyhow, you can spin a multiple,
the problem is to do eight 128s.

542
00:27:26.420 --> 00:27:29.960
I'm in a DS2 and I still won't
have support for four disks right?

543
00:27:29.960 --> 00:27:33.550
So I have to go up to an even higher tier
and it starts to get a little expensive.

544
00:27:33.550 --> 00:27:36.320
But now this one can handle more disks and
I can get that extra space in there.

545
00:27:36.320 --> 00:27:38.740
So pretty good solution all in all.

546
00:27:38.740 --> 00:27:40.830
>> And
Microsoft says that this is best practice.

547
00:27:40.830 --> 00:27:42.490
Right?
If you need those IOPS then you

548
00:27:42.490 --> 00:27:45.280
start adding those smaller disks and
get all the IOPS that you need.

549
00:27:45.280 --> 00:27:48.700
You're still going up to that one
terabyte limit that they allow for.

550
00:27:48.700 --> 00:27:50.330
So that's nice of them.

551
00:27:50.330 --> 00:27:52.720
Say, hey man there's more than
one way to skin this cat.

552
00:27:52.720 --> 00:27:54.200
>> Yeah, and that's exactly right.

553
00:27:54.200 --> 00:27:55.600
You just choose the option that works for

554
00:27:55.600 --> 00:27:58.280
you and you can always change
your mind later, right?

555
00:27:58.280 --> 00:28:01.060
A lot of this stuff's really easy to
manipulate and change after the fact.

556
00:28:01.060 --> 00:28:01.630
>> Awesome.

557
00:28:01.630 --> 00:28:03.580
Well Don,
this has been a whole lot of fun and

00:28:03.580 --> 00:28:05.470
a very interesting topic
to be honest with you.

559
00:28:05.470 --> 00:28:08.640
Is there anything else that we need to
know about provisioning these drives or

00:28:08.640 --> 00:28:10.190
creating the storage spaces?

>> That's about it on this one.

00:28:11.500 --> 00:28:14.720

00:28:20.210 --> 00:28:20.960

00:28:20.960 --> 00:28:23.000
Definitely something that you'll

00:28:26.580 --> 00:28:27.520

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel explore Microsoft's *Azure Files* as a common network storage solution between Virtual Machines. First they run down some of the basic functions and limitations of Azure Files. Then they walk you through creating an Azure File share using the Azure Portal and by using the PowerShell.
episodes.title: Azure Files
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.359 --> 00:00:16.678
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.678 --> 00:00:19.440
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

4
00:00:19.440 --> 00:00:23.098
we're gonna continue taking a look at
Microsoft's Azure Virtual Machines.

5
00:00:23.098 --> 00:00:27.486
And joining us again here on the program
is none other than my good friend

6
00:00:27.486 --> 00:00:28.373
Mr Don Pezet.

7
00:00:28.373 --> 00:00:31.309
Don, thanks for joining us today,
welcome to the show, how you doing?

8
00:00:31.309 --> 00:00:33.353
>> I am doing great Daniel and
glad to be back.

9
00:00:33.353 --> 00:00:36.668
We're gonna be talking about some neat
stuff today because we've seen a lot of

10
00:00:36.668 --> 00:00:39.343
Azure storage technologies, and
a lot of it is kinda complex.

11
00:00:39.343 --> 00:00:42.164
You gotta add in disks and
do all this management, worry about I/O’s.

12
00:00:42.164 --> 00:00:47.689
But sometimes, we just need quick, dirty,
easy storage available for our machines.

13
00:00:47.689 --> 00:00:51.682
And there's actually a neat feature built
into Azure called Azure Files that we can

14
00:00:51.682 --> 00:00:54.667
take advantage of,
that doesn't even require our servers.

15
00:00:54.667 --> 00:00:55.642
Pretty cool.

16
00:00:55.642 --> 00:00:56.628
So we're gonna take a look at that today.

17
00:00:56.628 --> 00:00:58.463
>> The heck you say, Don.

18
00:00:58.463 --> 00:01:01.968
I can't imagine having a server but
I didn't have to really make a server.

19
00:01:01.968 --> 00:01:02.769
>> Yeah.

20
00:01:02.769 --> 00:01:04.662
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, this one's easy.

21
00:01:04.662 --> 00:01:06.933
One of the most common scenarios for

22
00:01:06.933 --> 00:01:10.125
files is what we call like
the central file store.

23
00:01:10.125 --> 00:01:13.088
So, at your office you'd probably
had a shared files somewhere and

24
00:01:13.088 --> 00:01:14.548
it gets mapped to a drive letter.

25
00:01:14.548 --> 00:01:17.950
Maybe it's my Z drive.

26
00:01:17.950 --> 00:01:20.356
And so every employee knows like,
oh, if I wanna share files for

27
00:01:20.356 --> 00:01:21.664
other people I'll put in Z drive.

28
00:01:21.664 --> 00:01:25.304
Well, we've been creating data disks and
attaching them to a VM,

29
00:01:25.304 --> 00:01:27.063
but the data disks do not share.

30
00:01:27.063 --> 00:01:29.802
They're only visible
to that particular VM.

31
00:01:29.802 --> 00:01:34.027
And sure, in Windows we can share a folder
out, or in Linux you can set up NFS and

32
00:01:34.027 --> 00:01:34.807
share it out.

33
00:01:34.807 --> 00:01:37.765
But it's actually pretty hard to
get two VM’s to talk to each other,

34
00:01:37.765 --> 00:01:40.888
cuz there's a lot of security measures
in place that isolate the VM's.

35
00:01:40.888 --> 00:01:44.510
So there's not really a great way to
share files in between those VMs, right?

36
00:01:44.510 --> 00:01:48.563
Well, there's Azure Files,
which actually fills that gap.

37
00:01:48.563 --> 00:01:52.101
What Azure Files does is,
it lets us create a shared folder, an SMB,

38
00:01:52.101 --> 00:01:56.328
a server message block share, just like
Windows uses for sharing in a workgroup.

39
00:01:56.328 --> 00:01:58.776
We can create a shared folder, and

40
00:01:58.776 --> 00:02:03.259
it can be stored directly in Azure and
not attached to a server.

41
00:02:03.259 --> 00:02:07.016
And that means that any of your virtual
machines that are in the same region,

42
00:02:07.016 --> 00:02:10.535
it is tied to a region, any virtual
machine you have that's in that same

43
00:02:10.535 --> 00:02:14.347
region will be able to access that shared
folder as if it was stored on an actual

44
00:02:14.347 --> 00:02:16.725
server somewhere,
except there is no server.

45
00:02:16.725 --> 00:02:18.246
We just create the shared folder.

46
00:02:18.246 --> 00:02:19.605
Azure takes care of it for us.

47
00:02:19.605 --> 00:02:21.898
That means it is pretty easy to deploy,
and

48
00:02:21.898 --> 00:02:26.187
it's pretty useful cuz I'm not having to
pay for extra CPU cycles or whatever.

49
00:02:26.187 --> 00:02:29.020
I just have the storage available,
and it's shared between my systems.

50
00:02:29.020 --> 00:02:32.633
A great example of this might be that you
have some third party software that you

51
00:02:32.633 --> 00:02:34.023
install on all your servers.

52
00:02:34.023 --> 00:02:36.984
And so every time you spin up a new
server, you gotta install the software,

53
00:02:36.984 --> 00:02:39.533
but you don't wanna copy the software
to the server every time.

54
00:02:39.533 --> 00:02:42.547
So what you could do is you could
set up an Azure File Share,

55
00:02:42.547 --> 00:02:46.606
stick your software in that Azure File
Share, and now whenever you spin up a new

56
00:02:46.606 --> 00:02:50.504
serve,r you can just have it connect
to that share and load that software.

57
00:02:50.504 --> 00:02:52.803
You can even write a script to do it,
so it just automatically grabs it and

58
00:02:52.803 --> 00:02:54.671
installs it right off of that share and
it's pretty cool.

59
00:02:54.671 --> 00:02:59.548
Now using the Legacy portal I guess
that's really a bad way to put it.

60
00:02:59.548 --> 00:03:00.437
You couldn't use the Legacy portal,

61
00:03:00.437 --> 00:03:02.009
you had to do everything through
the PowerShell on the old system.

62
00:03:02.009 --> 00:03:05.344
But the new preview portal which,
actually I've gotta stop calling

63
00:03:05.344 --> 00:03:09.370
it the preview portal cuz as of just this
morning, I'm gonna time this episode, so

64
00:03:09.370 --> 00:03:12.074
if you're watching this in the future,
this morning,

65
00:03:12.074 --> 00:03:15.951
Microsoft switched the preview portal
to actually be the official portal now.

66
00:03:15.951 --> 00:03:19.981
So in the new portal, I guess I'll call it
that, you can actually create Azure file

67
00:03:19.981 --> 00:03:23.160
shares right there in the UI, so
it's actually really easy now.

68
00:03:23.160 --> 00:03:25.607
You whip them up,
you get your machines connected to it, and

69
00:03:25.607 --> 00:03:27.003
you've got a central file share.

70
00:03:27.003 --> 00:03:27.781
>> Very cool stuff.

71
00:03:27.781 --> 00:03:30.520
>> All right, so
let's see how that's done.

72
00:03:30.520 --> 00:03:32.320
It's actually pretty, pretty easy.

73
00:03:32.320 --> 00:03:35.825
So I'm going to jump into my
portal here and the Azure files,

74
00:03:35.825 --> 00:03:37.904
they're not attached to a server.

75
00:03:37.904 --> 00:03:40.851
So normally I'm used to jumping
into like my virtual machines and

76
00:03:40.851 --> 00:03:41.827
starting to do work.

77
00:03:41.827 --> 00:03:44.103
I'm actually going to go down
here to storage accounts.

78
00:03:44.103 --> 00:03:48.781
Right, your Azure file shares
are stored right in a storage account,

79
00:03:48.781 --> 00:03:51.249
just like a VHD for a server would be.

80
00:03:51.249 --> 00:03:54.174
All right, now an important thing here.

81
00:03:54.174 --> 00:03:58.572
The storage account that you use
has to be in the same region as

82
00:03:58.572 --> 00:04:00.909
the servers that connect to it.

83
00:04:00.909 --> 00:04:04.644
So if I have a storage account in US West
and I've got a server in US East,

84
00:04:04.644 --> 00:04:06.283
it's not gonna see the share.

85
00:04:06.283 --> 00:04:09.480
But if I have storage account in
US East and a server in US East,

86
00:04:09.480 --> 00:04:13.248
they'll be able to see each other,
right, so I've gotta choose that.

87
00:04:13.248 --> 00:04:17.055
If I look at my servers,
where are my servers here?

88
00:04:17.055 --> 00:04:20.294
I've got, I think I've only got one server
powered on right now, ITProTV demo1.

89
00:04:20.294 --> 00:04:25.109
And if I look at this guy, I can see
over here what region it's in and

90
00:04:25.109 --> 00:04:27.272
kind of where it's sitting.

91
00:04:27.272 --> 00:04:28.804
Or at least I say I can.

92
00:04:28.804 --> 00:04:31.347
Let me jump into its properties, and
we'll figure out where this guy's parked.

93
00:04:31.347 --> 00:04:34.829
And hopefully it's in US East 2.

94
00:04:34.829 --> 00:04:37.047
That's where I normally stick my systems,
I'm sure it is.

95
00:04:37.047 --> 00:04:38.347
There East US 2, all right.

96
00:04:38.347 --> 00:04:39.389
So if I have a storage group
that's in East US 2, then,

97
00:04:39.389 --> 00:04:40.843
I'll be able to create an Azure File Share
and we'll be able to connect to it.

98
00:04:40.843 --> 00:04:47.520
So, I'm gonna go under storage accounts,
and, I'm actually got a ton that

99
00:04:47.520 --> 00:04:53.097
are in East US 2 including ITProTV
demo1 which is that server.

100
00:04:53.097 --> 00:04:54.501
It's got it's own storage account.

101
00:04:54.501 --> 00:04:57.224
So I could use that, or
I can use something shared like this one,

102
00:04:57.224 --> 00:04:58.240
itprotvdemostorage.

103
00:04:58.240 --> 00:04:59.563
In fact, I'll use that one.

104
00:04:59.563 --> 00:05:00.782
It's in East US 2.

105
00:05:00.782 --> 00:05:05.065
When you browse into the storage account,
you'll see where you can pull up

106
00:05:05.065 --> 00:05:10.174
the settings, and right down here we've
got blobs, files, tables and queues, okay?

107
00:05:10.174 --> 00:05:13.692
Well, blobs, those are our
virtual hard drives, our VHDs.

108
00:05:13.692 --> 00:05:16.617
That's where our server storage is going.

109
00:05:16.617 --> 00:05:21.066
But files, those are files that
we can just drop right in and

110
00:05:21.066 --> 00:05:23.559
we can set up an Azure File Share.

111
00:05:23.559 --> 00:05:25.533
So that's basically where
we're gonna do that.

112
00:05:25.533 --> 00:05:30.388
If we jump into that, the screen is
gonna update here real quick, and

113
00:05:30.388 --> 00:05:35.772
we'll start to see the file service and
some of the settings are available.

00:26:03.210 --> 00:26:08.910
So maybe this one will be 3390
on the public port Versus 3389.

513
00:26:08.910 --> 00:26:13.790
And so, if I wanna connect a file
of three, I can RDP to 3389.

514
00:26:13.790 --> 00:26:17.080
But if I wanna connect to file 04,

00:26:17.080 --> 00:26:21.810
I can RDP into 3390, and it will translate
it to 3389 before it hits the server.

516
00:26:21.810 --> 00:26:27.610
So I don't have to change the server, the
VM It's the cloud services doing that for

517
00:26:27.610 --> 00:26:30.500
me, but
I do that to avoid having a duplicate.

518
00:26:31.980 --> 00:26:35.430
There's other options in here for
doing things like auto-scale and stuff.

519
00:26:35.430 --> 00:26:39.340
We'll see those in another episode, but
I'll just go ahead and complete this.

520
00:26:39.340 --> 00:26:43.010
And that's gonna deploy that virtual
machine into that cloud service.

521
00:26:43.010 --> 00:26:46.990
And I can have, if they're single-core,
I can have up to 20 of them in there.

522
00:26:46.990 --> 00:26:49.020
If they're dual-core,
I am have ten of them in there.

523
00:26:49.020 --> 00:26:52.430
And if I need more,
I can either create more cloud services or

524
00:26:52.430 --> 00:26:55.720
I can reach out to Microsoft support and
see if they can bend that limit for me and

525
00:26:55.720 --> 00:26:57.110
then we can get some more in there.

526
00:26:57.110 --> 00:27:01.940
So that's basically how these cloud
services work and how they function.

527
00:27:01.940 --> 00:27:05.540
They're really important because
they're creating that public IP.

528
00:27:05.540 --> 00:27:09.450
Now, I just wanna add one more thing
on this before we kinda wind down.

529
00:27:09.450 --> 00:27:12.790
That public IP, that's what
you're supposed to be using for

530
00:27:12.790 --> 00:27:15.400
your customers to access these resources.

531
00:27:15.400 --> 00:27:17.570
Because it gets a dns name.

532
00:27:17.570 --> 00:27:21.830
When I go into the dashboard, and
let's see if I can get over here.

533
00:27:21.830 --> 00:27:24.910
When I go into the dashboard and I look at
the settings there's that public IP and

534
00:27:24.910 --> 00:27:26.570
there's that DNS name.

535
00:27:26.570 --> 00:27:29.180
I can map a See name to
that no big deal and

00:27:29.180 --> 00:27:31.370
now I've got something that
people can access reliably.

537
00:27:32.570 --> 00:27:36.440
But, I can actually go
into my virtual machines.

538
00:27:36.440 --> 00:27:41.420
And in a virtual machine, like if I
just take itprotv demo 1 here, this guy.

539
00:27:41.420 --> 00:27:44.300
You can create what's
called a per instance IP,

540
00:27:44.300 --> 00:27:48.480
an IP address that's designed
just to this instance.

541
00:27:48.480 --> 00:27:51.570
And then, that means that this
guy will have a public IP.

542
00:27:51.570 --> 00:27:53.840
And when I look at this guy,
see over here,

543
00:27:53.840 --> 00:27:58.680
I've got this like, public virtual IP or
VIP address, and it's just empty?

544
00:27:58.680 --> 00:28:00.440
There's no instance IP on it.

545
00:28:00.440 --> 00:28:03.450
By default you don't have an instance
IP on your virtual machines.

546
00:28:03.450 --> 00:28:06.690
They rely on that resource group for
their public IP.

547
00:28:06.690 --> 00:28:11.300
If you assign one, what happens is,
it's assigned to that one, but

548
00:28:11.300 --> 00:28:13.240
it doesn't get a DNS name.

549
00:28:13.240 --> 00:28:15.070
And so
there's nothing you can map a c name to.

550
00:28:15.070 --> 00:28:18.720
You could map an a record to it, but
if this server were ever to fail over or

551
00:28:18.720 --> 00:28:21.520
have it's IP changed,
your record would break.

552
00:28:21.520 --> 00:28:25.020
And so Microsoft does that on purpose,
cuz they don't want you to use that.

553
00:28:25.020 --> 00:28:26.940
You gotta have a specific reason.

554
00:28:26.940 --> 00:28:30.280
I might have a five node cluster and
I've got a specific reason that I need to

555
00:28:30.280 --> 00:28:34.820
connect to node number three, and so
I go ahead and assign it a public IP.

556
00:28:34.820 --> 00:28:36.340
Otherwise, they have private IPs and

557
00:28:36.340 --> 00:28:40.820
I can connect via those, and that's how
I can manage those individual systems.

558
00:28:40.820 --> 00:28:45.200
So just be aware that you can
assign IPs to individual machines.

559
00:28:45.200 --> 00:28:47.650
But you're really supposed to use
the ones on the cloud service,

560
00:28:47.650 --> 00:28:50.190
cuz those are the ones
that get the DNS name, and

561
00:28:50.190 --> 00:28:54.840
that means we can use them in a redundant
manner and not worry about failure.

562
00:28:54.840 --> 00:28:55.610
>> Well awesome stuff, Don.

563
00:28:55.610 --> 00:28:58.200
I'm understanding cloud
services as an important thing.

564

565

566

567

>> You know, while I was going
through that configuration,

00:29:09.160 --> 00:29:11.070
you might of noticed some of
those other tabs in there,

569
00:29:11.070 --> 00:29:13.780
things like
>> Availability sets, and

low balancing sets, and those things.

00:29:16.040 --> 00:29:19.970
Those are all dependent on

572
00:29:19.970 --> 00:29:21.530
And we're gonna see those later on.

573
00:29:21.530 --> 00:29:23.810
We'll do an episode specifically

00:29:23.810 --> 00:29:25.550
an episode specifically

575
00:29:25.550 --> 00:29:28.350
So, we're gonna see those later on,

576
00:29:28.350 --> 00:29:31.360
But I wanted to make sure we tackled
that basic knowledge we need for

00:29:31.360 --> 00:29:34.340
a cloud service so we understand that so
we can add onto it later and

00:29:34.340 --> 00:29:36.160
it will all kind of make sense and

579
00:29:36.160 --> 00:29:37.210
>> Excellent Don, well thank you so

00:29:37.210 --> 00:29:40.610
much for explaining this little
confusing topping to us.

581
00:29:40.610 --> 00:29:42.620
Cuz we're gonna need it down
the line obviously we got some

582
00:29:42.620 --> 00:29:43.840
shows coming up for that.

583
00:29:43.840 --> 00:29:46.880
Thank you guys for watching, we're gonna
go ahead and sign off for ITProTV.

584

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel describe Microsoft Azure's *Resource Groups*. They start off by explaining how Resource Groups are replacing Cloud Services as a way to group Azure resources, hence the name. Then they take a look at what Resource Groups can do that Cloud Services cannot. Also talked about are: monitoring, load balancing, and Core Quotas.
episodes.title: Resource Groups

hey I'll say resource group.

cuz that's kind of important.

And how they really
are the way to use Azure now,

00:01:07.030 --> 00:01:09.500
extremely important to everything

>> Well Don I guess the first question

replaced cloud services is,

shortest episode ever, we're done.

00:02:05.180 --> 00:02:06.250
I mentioned in cloud services,

00:02:19.190 --> 00:02:21.170
It's easy to lose track of that.

00:02:21.170 --> 00:02:23.896
Putting them all into a cloud service,
when you delete out that cloud

00:02:23.896 --> 00:02:27.500
service you can delete all the VMs and

00:02:27.500 --> 00:02:31.040
But what about all the other

00:02:31.040 --> 00:02:34.130
Things like virtual networks,
network interfaces,

00:02:34.130 --> 00:02:38.330
additional virtual IPs,
what about all that stuff?

58
00:02:38.330 --> 00:02:41.925
Well when you create a cloud service,
all those other things are stored outside

00:02:41.925 --> 00:02:45.466
the cloud service, and they still get
left behind, and you still have to go and

00:02:45.466 --> 00:02:47.468

00:02:47.468 --> 00:02:50.518

At the end of the day, it probably costs

00:02:55.348 --> 00:02:57.640
it's probably not a big deal,

00:03:09.794 --> 00:03:14.480

00:03:14.480 --> 00:03:16.721

00:03:16.721 --> 00:03:18.796

00:03:18.796 --> 00:03:22.423

00:03:22.423 --> 00:03:24.206
detritus or however you say that,

00:03:31.880 --> 00:03:35.170
wipe the whole thing out I'll figure

00:03:35.170 --> 00:03:37.180
But with resource groups we don't
have that problem, so really,

00:03:37.180 --> 00:03:38.700
really cool stuff.

All right, so, just to kinda give you

00:03:53.830 --> 00:03:56.590

00:03:56.590 --> 00:03:58.150
So when you start working
with the resource

00:03:58.150 --> 00:03:59.440
groups you're not going to see that.

Now, I need to throw out

00:04:01.450 --> 00:04:06.360
I don't wanna throw us under too much
jargon today but you're going to hear or

00:04:06.360 --> 00:04:10.270
see mentioned in the Azure portal about
something called the resource manager.

89
00:04:10.270 --> 00:04:10.923
All right,

90
00:04:10.923 --> 00:04:15.307
the resource manager is what's actually
controlling these resource groups.

00:04:15.307 --> 00:04:19.183
And so when we deploy a virtual machine,

00:04:19.183 --> 00:04:22.842
a virtual machine using the classic

00:04:22.842 --> 00:04:25.760
And the classic method,
that's saying let's use a cloud service.

00:04:25.760 --> 00:04:29.820
And the resource manager method,

00:04:29.820 --> 00:04:32.620
So that's a big difference when

00:04:32.620 --> 00:04:33.850
But when you create them,

00:04:33.850 --> 00:04:38.650
you'll see I've got a resource group

00:04:38.650 --> 00:04:41.929
And that web demo,
that's a resource group, and inside of it,

99
00:04:41.929 --> 00:04:45.842
I've got two virtual machines,

00:04:45.842 --> 00:04:48.560
Those two virtual machines
are in this one resource group.

101
00:04:48.560 --> 00:04:51.850
I'm using it like a cloud service, right?

00:04:51.850 --> 00:04:56.420
But if I go into that resource group,

00:04:56.420 --> 00:04:59.190
I've got ITProTV demo,

00:04:59.190 --> 00:05:00.140
And down here,

00:05:00.140 --> 00:05:04.910
I can see resources that are in it,

00:05:04.910 --> 00:05:06.110
I mean, look at that list.

00:05:06.110 --> 00:05:09.520
I've got some virtual machines,

00:05:09.520 --> 00:05:12.480
But then after that,

00:05:39.090 --> 00:05:42.194

00:05:42.194 --> 00:05:46.200
well if I stop messing with my mouse,

00:05:46.200 --> 00:05:49.120
Here's the public IP address that's

00:05:49.120 --> 00:05:53.100

00:05:53.100 --> 00:05:57.120

00:05:57.120 --> 00:06:00.940

00:06:11.830 --> 00:06:15.130

00:06:15.130 --> 00:06:19.463

00:06:19.463 --> 00:06:21.072
or another zone in a region.

00:06:21.072 --> 00:06:25.565
All of this stuff is going to

00:06:31.360 --> 00:06:36.930
So that's part of what resource groups do,

00:06:37.960 --> 00:06:40.680
The other thing is,

Now why would I do that?

To group them together for

it's separate and you don't see it.

594
00:29:27.540 --> 00:29:29.060
But it will deploy and
we'll start to have it.

595
00:29:29.060 --> 00:29:34.110
So, we can rapidly deploy clusters
of information, and we'll have it.

596
00:29:34.110 --> 00:29:37.560
Now one quick word of caution.

597
00:29:37.560 --> 00:29:40.400
When you deploy this stuff
inside of a resource group,

598
00:29:40.400 --> 00:29:44.140
it's different than when you deploy
it inside of a cloud service, and

599
00:29:44.140 --> 00:29:46.430
it's represented differently in the UI.

600
00:29:46.430 --> 00:29:52.320
So in the UI, I've got virtual machines
classic, and virtual machines regular.

601
00:29:52.320 --> 00:29:55.640
And so now I've got VMs
spread in between the two.

602
00:29:55.640 --> 00:29:58.340
And that's something I need to
be I need to be wary of, right?

603
00:29:58.340 --> 00:30:01.300
Is that when I'm looking inside of one
set of VMs I'm not necessarily seeing

604
00:30:01.300 --> 00:30:02.760
all of the virtual machines on my account.

605
00:30:02.760 --> 00:30:04.610
So when you're monitoring cost and

606
00:30:04.610 --> 00:30:07.590
things of that nature,
your stuff starts to get spread out.

607
00:30:07.590 --> 00:30:11.900
So I encourage you make the transition
to resource groups as soon as you can,

608
00:30:11.900 --> 00:30:13.680
and just get out of cloud
services altogether,

609
00:30:13.680 --> 00:30:15.960
that way you don't have to go to
two places just to look for things.

610
00:30:15.960 --> 00:30:20.750
But if you look at my account for example,
if I go here under virtual machines,

611
00:30:20.750 --> 00:30:23.602
I only see a couple of VMs.

612
00:30:23.602 --> 00:30:25.640
itprotv-file05, web-demo-1, web-demo-2.

613
00:30:25.640 --> 00:30:30.070
I still don't see my db5 yet
but it'll come up.

614
00:30:30.070 --> 00:30:32.551
So these are ones that were
deployed in resource groups, and

615
00:30:32.551 --> 00:30:36.820
then when I go to virtual machines
classic, that's where I start to see all

616
00:30:36.820 --> 00:30:41.200
these other ones that I
made in the previous model.

617
00:30:41.200 --> 00:30:43.700
And notice, there's itprotv-file04,

618
00:30:43.700 --> 00:30:48.710
which I made the old way and actually
put it inside of a resource group.

619
00:30:48.710 --> 00:30:52.400
That shows how it's kind of
an old model VM that's been

620
00:30:52.400 --> 00:30:54.190
placed in a resource
group at the same time.

621
00:30:54.190 --> 00:30:55.500
So you can kinda do both.

622
00:30:55.500 --> 00:30:57.770
So really neat stuff, really powerful.

623
00:30:57.770 --> 00:31:01.330
One thing you're gonna want to learn more
about, are making those template files.

624
00:31:01.330 --> 00:31:04.940
And Microsoft has a great website, I'll
put a link for it in the show notes for

625
00:31:04.940 --> 00:31:06.050
this episode.

626
00:31:06.050 --> 00:31:09.930
But they've got this Authoring Azure
Resource Manager Templates, and

627
00:31:09.930 --> 00:31:11.000
it's a great read.

628
00:31:11.000 --> 00:31:12.110
They update this all the time.

629
00:31:12.110 --> 00:31:14.420
It was updated five days ago.

630
00:31:14.420 --> 00:31:17.190
So that's how often
they're updating this one.

631
00:31:17.190 --> 00:31:20.690
And boy, it just has some
really great stuff in here on

632
00:31:20.690 --> 00:31:24.683
how to build the template, how to use
expressions, variables, resources, and

633
00:31:24.683 --> 00:31:29.280
just how we can really whip
up a custom environment.

634
00:31:29.280 --> 00:31:33.188
I was telling Daniel before the show,
the stuff you can do with this is amazing.

635
00:31:33.188 --> 00:31:37.950
You can have it deploy and create an
Active Directory and join the machines to

636
00:31:37.950 --> 00:31:42.068
the domain and have a certain
configuration, all right out of the box.

637
00:31:42.068 --> 00:31:46.137
And it's really pretty impressive stuff
if you take the time to learn it.

638
00:31:46.137 --> 00:31:51.190
>> Yeah, these resource groups are very,
very awesome, very, very powerful.

639
00:31:51.190 --> 00:31:53.880
And then we have the, well I guess
it's like a scripting language almost.

640
00:31:53.880 --> 00:31:56.452
You learn that and
you are a force to be reckoned with.

641
00:31:56.452 --> 00:31:58.820
You're gonna be able to use
this to your utmost benefit.

642
00:31:58.820 --> 00:32:02.260
Now, Don, is there anything else that
we need to know about them before we

643
00:32:02.260 --> 00:32:03.470
close the show?

644
00:32:03.470 --> 00:32:06.790
Well, what we saw here was creating
a resource group, and kinda what they do.

645
00:32:06.790 --> 00:32:09.870
We're gonna work more with them as we
start to configure load balancing,

646
00:32:09.870 --> 00:32:12.860
availability sets, all those other
advanced things that stack on top of them.

647
00:32:12.860 --> 00:32:15.440
And definitely watch
the networking episodes,

648
00:32:15.440 --> 00:32:17.950
where we'll cover
the network security groups.

649
00:32:17.950 --> 00:32:20.060
Cuz you'll deploy those on
the resource group instead of

650
00:32:20.060 --> 00:32:21.210
on the individual VMs too.

651
00:32:21.210 --> 00:32:22.500
That's another one
that's pretty important.

652
00:32:22.500 --> 00:32:24.960
So there's plenty more there.

653
00:32:24.960 --> 00:32:27.590
But as far as the resource groups
themselves, that's basically it.

654
00:32:27.590 --> 00:32:28.590
>> I see what you're doing there, Don.

655
00:32:28.590 --> 00:32:30.860
You're building
a foundational knowledge for

656
00:32:30.860 --> 00:32:33.270
us to build upon as we
move through the shows.

657
00:32:33.270 --> 00:32:34.740
I'm with you on that one.

658
00:32:34.740 --> 00:32:36.300
All right, Don, well,
that being said, thank you so

659
00:32:36.300 --> 00:32:40.610
much for showing us how to use
this option inside of Azure.

660
00:32:40.610 --> 00:32:43.700
But we've ticked down the clock, so
we're gonna go ahead and close her down.

661
00:32:43.700 --> 00:32:44.610
Thanks for watching.

662
00:32:44.610 --> 00:32:47.560
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

663
00:32:47.560 --> 00:32:48.210
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

>> And we'll see you next time.
