episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel dive into looking at Networking Azure Virtual Machines. They kick things off by defining and describing Virtual Networks(VN), both how they work as well as some of their limitations. Then they jump over to some guidelines to follow when implementing a Virtual Network in Azure. They also cover topics such as DNS in VNs and creating/configuring Network Security Groups which is basically the Azure firewall.
episodes.title: Virtual Machine Networking
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.571 --> 00:00:16.914
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.914 --> 00:00:18.744
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and

4
00:00:18.744 --> 00:00:22.647
in today's episode we're gonna continue
taking a look at the Microsoft Azure

5
00:00:22.647 --> 00:00:25.970
virtual machines there up inside
that Azure cloud service.

6
00:00:25.970 --> 00:00:27.300
And joining us yet again for

7
00:00:27.300 --> 00:00:31.810
another great episode here on ITProTV is
my good friend and colleague Mr Don Pezet.

8
00:00:31.810 --> 00:00:33.730
Don, welcome to the show,
how's it going today?

9
00:00:33.730 --> 00:00:36.360
>> Thanks for having me back, Daniel, and
I'm excited about today cuz we're gonna be

10
00:00:36.360 --> 00:00:40.130
talking a little bit about virtual
networking inside of Azure.

11
00:00:40.130 --> 00:00:43.010
You've probably noticed as we spun
these machines up, a lot of them had IP

12
00:00:43.010 --> 00:00:46.370
addresses, they had network connectivity,
they got it from somewhere.

13
00:00:46.370 --> 00:00:51.380
And I've accepted the defaults in darn
near every single episode this series.

14
00:00:51.380 --> 00:00:54.280
It's time we took a look at some of
the other options that are out there, and

15
00:00:54.280 --> 00:00:55.730
this is the episode for us.

16
00:00:55.730 --> 00:00:57.151
That's what we've got on the plate for
us today.

17
00:00:57.151 --> 00:01:00.030
>> Now Don,
obviously this is networking, but

18
00:01:00.030 --> 00:01:05.129
we're working inside of the Azure your
portal, so is it really any different?

19
00:01:05.129 --> 00:01:08.220
I mean, networking's networking
no matter where you go.

20
00:01:08.220 --> 00:01:10.090
Obviously we've got something
else to learn about this.

21
00:01:10.090 --> 00:01:13.635
>> Yeah, and well, they're just
like physical networks but virtual.

22
00:01:13.635 --> 00:01:15.910
>> [LAUGH]
>> So a lot of the knowledge you guys

23
00:01:15.910 --> 00:01:18.330
already have carries right over
to the virtual environment.

24
00:01:18.330 --> 00:01:20.802
We can deploy it right here and
it works great.

25
00:01:20.802 --> 00:01:24.442
So we don't have to do anything too crazy,
but there's a lot of little ins and outs,

26
00:01:24.442 --> 00:01:27.879
little quirks that we've gotta be aware
of, and so I wanna walk you through that

27
00:01:27.879 --> 00:01:30.578
process and kinda get that set up and
see it in an environment.

28
00:01:30.578 --> 00:01:34.550
So, first off just a couple of little
things about virtual networks.

29
00:01:34.550 --> 00:01:37.180
Whenever you spin up
a new resource group or

30
00:01:37.180 --> 00:01:41.040
even when you spin up a cloud service, you
always attach them to a virtual network,

31
00:01:41.040 --> 00:01:43.700
a network that represents your machines.

32
00:01:43.700 --> 00:01:46.290
And these are networks that
keep you separate from

33
00:01:46.290 --> 00:01:48.270
all the other Azure clients
that are out there.

34
00:01:48.270 --> 00:01:53.810
So you'll have a private network that's
just associated with your systems.

35
00:01:53.810 --> 00:01:57.010
And you may have more than one of these
networks dividing up your machines, and

36
00:01:57.010 --> 00:02:01.030
when you do that your new networks
that you create are kind of isolated

37
00:02:01.030 --> 00:02:01.970
from each other.

38
00:02:01.970 --> 00:02:04.850
And Microsoft sets up what's called
a gateway service that allows you to route

39
00:02:04.850 --> 00:02:05.990
between them, so

40
00:02:05.990 --> 00:02:09.510
you can create multiple subnets just
like you might do in a building.

41
00:02:09.510 --> 00:02:13.530
I might have five floors in a building and
I give each floor its own subnet.

42
00:02:13.530 --> 00:02:17.740
Well, in my virtual environment in Azure I
might create five different subnets,

43
00:02:17.740 --> 00:02:20.610
not to represent physical floors,
but to represent something else.

44
00:02:20.610 --> 00:02:23.740
I might have servers that
are exposed to the Internet, and

45
00:02:23.740 --> 00:02:25.480
servers that are not
exposed to the Internet.

46
00:02:25.480 --> 00:02:29.340
I might use two different subnets for that
so I can control traffic between them,

47
00:02:29.340 --> 00:02:33.090
and isolate out and protect the ones
I don't want exposed to the Internet.

48
00:02:33.090 --> 00:02:35.010
It's up to us how we wanna deploy it.

49
00:02:35.010 --> 00:02:37.890
At a minimum, you're gonna have
one virtual network, cuz your VMs

50
00:02:37.890 --> 00:02:42.070
have to go somewhere, but you can create
a really complex topology if you want.

51
00:02:42.070 --> 00:02:44.108
You can really lay out some
neat stuff in there, all right.

52
00:02:44.108 --> 00:02:47.630
>> I was gonna say, just because we have
an isolated network doesn't mean we don't

53
00:02:47.630 --> 00:02:49.270
need connectivity between them.

54
00:02:49.270 --> 00:02:53.610
Obviously we do isolation for certain
purposes as you just let us see, but

55
00:02:53.610 --> 00:02:57.030
how do I get them connected, how do I make
them talk and use that functionality?

56
00:02:57.030 --> 00:02:58.810
>> Yeah, so when we create these,

57
00:02:58.810 --> 00:03:02.560
the virtual networks are actually attached
to our subscription, to our account.

58
00:03:02.560 --> 00:03:05.840
And so what Microsoft does is it looks for
all of the virtual networks that are tied

59
00:03:05.840 --> 00:03:07.880
to your account and
they route between them.

60
00:03:07.880 --> 00:03:10.830
So they actually allow routing between
those systems, and what we'll see later,

61
00:03:10.830 --> 00:03:12.700
we can actually filter that type of stuff.

62
00:03:12.700 --> 00:03:16.040
But you have connectivity so as you
start deploying these virtual subnets,

63
00:03:16.040 --> 00:03:20.130
you just make them up willy-nilly, and
Microsoft actually attaches them together.

64
00:03:20.130 --> 00:03:22.630
And you've got this fully
routed multi-network

65
00:03:22.630 --> 00:03:24.260
environment that's pretty powerful.

66
00:03:24.260 --> 00:03:28.180
Now, even if I don't have a specific
need for multiple networks,

67
00:03:28.180 --> 00:03:31.210
there are times where I'm gonna
have to create them anyway.

68
00:03:31.210 --> 00:03:34.173
Mainly it's gonna center
around scalability,

69
00:03:34.173 --> 00:03:36.780
virtual networks are limited to 50 VMs.

70
00:03:36.780 --> 00:03:40.142
So I can have 50 virtual machines in one
of my virtual networks and if I need more,

71
00:03:40.142 --> 00:03:42.655
I'm gonna need to create a second
virtual network for that.

72
00:03:42.655 --> 00:03:47.315
And so I may need many subnets to add up
to get the full amount of virtual machines

73
00:03:47.315 --> 00:03:48.440
that I want.

74
00:03:48.440 --> 00:03:50.350
That can affect things like auto scaling,

75
00:03:50.350 --> 00:03:53.200
cuz what if I wanna auto
scale more than 50 systems?

76
00:03:53.200 --> 00:03:54.800
I'm gonna spin up another subnet.

77
00:03:54.800 --> 00:03:59.030
Fortunately, I can have one virtual
network with multiple virtual subnets

78
00:03:59.030 --> 00:04:01.600
inside of it, which means I can
auto scale across all of them.

79
00:04:01.600 --> 00:04:04.900
And you can grow to a very
large network if you wanted,

80
00:04:04.900 --> 00:04:06.840
it's pretty impressive
what's available to us.

81
00:04:06.840 --> 00:04:08.550
It's neat how the system works.

82
00:04:09.640 --> 00:04:12.805
All right, so let's talk a little
bit about how that system works and

83
00:04:12.805 --> 00:04:14.210
kinda some of the stuff that's there.

84
00:04:14.210 --> 00:04:15.890
What we're gonna do is we're
gonna go into Azure and

85
00:04:15.890 --> 00:04:17.210
we're gonna create a virtual network.

86
00:04:17.210 --> 00:04:18.940
And I'll just show you on one of mine.

87
00:04:20.720 --> 00:04:23.300
Let's spin up an all new
resource group here so

88
00:04:23.300 --> 00:04:24.450
I'm kinda starting fresh and clean.

89
00:04:24.450 --> 00:04:27.330
I've got so much stuff deployed
from all the episodes we've done.

90
00:04:27.330 --> 00:04:31.800
I'm gonna add a new resource group and
I'll just call this as like the ITProTV

91
00:04:31.800 --> 00:04:37.080
net demo or something,
itprotvnetdemo, all right.

92
00:04:37.080 --> 00:04:41.110
And I'll put it in US East,
I won't pin it to my dashboard, all right.

93
00:04:41.110 --> 00:04:42.860
So I'm creating a resource group, and

94
00:04:42.860 --> 00:04:46.300
my resource group is not gonna be very
flashy or exciting or anything like that.

95
00:04:46.300 --> 00:04:48.560
In fact it's not even show up,
let me refresh.

96
00:04:48.560 --> 00:04:50.625
[LAUGH] And we'll find that one.

97
00:04:50.625 --> 00:04:54.655
But basically when I whip up that resource
group it doesn't have a lot of stuff

98
00:04:54.655 --> 00:04:58.933
in it, all right, which might be a bit of
an over statement cuz it is technically,

99
00:04:58.933 --> 00:05:00.440
completely empty, right.

100
00:05:00.440 --> 00:05:03.230
So there's absolutely nothing
in that resource group.

101
00:05:03.230 --> 00:05:07.680
So if I start throwing virtual machines
in there, some neat things happen.

102
00:05:07.680 --> 00:05:10.060
If I throw a virtual machine
into this empty resource group,

00:05:10.060 --> 00:05:14.300
that first virtual machine
will create a network for me.

104
00:05:14.300 --> 00:05:17.590
It'll create it and all the settings from

00:05:17.590 --> 00:05:20.370
very first virtual machine,
it's basically gonna define it for me.

106
00:05:20.370 --> 00:05:24.500
But if I wanna do it ahead of time,
I can do it, I can come in here and

107
00:05:24.500 --> 00:05:27.520
define that virtual network and
really get this stuff set up.

108
00:05:27.520 --> 00:05:30.970
So I'm just gonna hit add and
I'm gonna type virtual network so

109
00:05:30.970 --> 00:05:33.960
I can find my virtual
networks here in the gallery.

110
00:05:33.960 --> 00:05:39.070
And once we've got a virtual network we
can start to provide our various settings.

111
00:05:39.070 --> 00:05:41.590
And it's asking if I want to do classic or

112
00:05:41.590 --> 00:05:45.140
I'll do the resource manager cuz that's
really what we wanna use from now on for

00:05:45.140 --> 00:05:46.120
our new deployments.

114
00:05:47.160 --> 00:05:49.460
Now once I choose that,
it's gonna let me create it, and

115
00:05:49.460 --> 00:05:52.780
even though I chose the resource manager
model, it is actually gonna create

116
00:05:52.780 --> 00:05:56.850
the underlying classic model for this too,
it gives us backward compatibility.

117
00:05:56.850 --> 00:06:00.580
But it's gonna ask me to
name my virtual network and

118
00:06:00.580 --> 00:06:02.840
to pick an address space for it.

119
00:06:02.840 --> 00:06:07.480
So I'm gonna call this my demo-network,
right.

120
00:06:07.480 --> 00:06:09.350
And will it let me do hyphens on this one?

121
00:06:09.350 --> 00:06:13.180
I always forget, some of them will let you

122
00:06:13.180 --> 00:06:17.210
So I'm gonna give it a name, and

Now, don't confuse this with a subnet,

124
00:06:19.940 --> 00:06:21.450
they think they're creating a subnet.

125
00:06:21.450 --> 00:06:23.200
What you're creating is
your address space, and

126
00:06:23.200 --> 00:06:25.750
you'll create subnets inside of it.

127
00:06:25.750 --> 00:06:28.990
So we're basically establishing
this overall address space, and

128
00:06:28.990 --> 00:06:32.860
it's picking by default from
a pretty big network here.

129
00:06:32.860 --> 00:06:35.750
Mine's 10.3,
I have to be careful not to overlap.

130
00:06:35.750 --> 00:06:39.980
So if I pick 10.2,
I'm using that in a different environment.

131
00:06:39.980 --> 00:06:41.964
See it was telling me it's
in my itprotvdemonet,

132
00:06:41.964 --> 00:06:44.860
which kinda looks like demon net or
something, I don't know, anyhow.

133
00:06:44.860 --> 00:06:48.941
So I'm overlapping with another network,
if I do 10.1 we can see that ones in

134
00:06:48.941 --> 00:06:53.143
itprotv-fileservers, so I've got to make
sure I pick one that's not in use, but

135
00:06:53.143 --> 00:06:56.450
I have a lot of flexibility here
as far as what I wanna pick.

136
00:06:56.450 --> 00:06:59.720
I could even jump to a completely
different space, for example,

137
00:06:59.720 --> 00:07:02.240
I might want to do 172.16.0.0/16,
like that, and

138
00:07:02.240 --> 00:07:08.310
see how it updated to reflect it.

139
00:07:08.310 --> 00:07:13.030
I'm creating an address space that's
got 65,000 IP addresses in it, so

140
00:07:13.030 --> 00:07:15.380
you can pick from different
networks if you want.

141
00:07:15.380 --> 00:07:19.040
You can give it a name, I'm just gonna
call mine default, and this is for

142
00:07:19.040 --> 00:07:20.050
the subnet.

143
00:07:20.050 --> 00:07:24.990
The subnet is inside of that virtual
network and I'm creating the first one.

144
00:07:24.990 --> 00:07:29.000
So I did a /16 here for my address space.

145
00:07:29.000 --> 00:07:31.760
For my subnet I'm gonna pick
something inside of it.

146
00:07:31.760 --> 00:07:37.859
So my default one might be 172.16.0.0/24,

00:29:28.515 --> 00:29:29.305
>> Simon says in there.

598
00:29:29.305 --> 00:29:30.995
>> There we go.
So now it's gonna load, and so

599
00:29:30.995 --> 00:29:34.075
now it's got that one
subnet associated with it.

600
00:29:34.075 --> 00:29:36.245
And I could go and
add more if I needed to, but

601
00:29:36.245 --> 00:29:39.640
it's got that subnet in the network
interfaces and once we've got that in

602
00:29:39.640 --> 00:29:43.740
place, on the right side you can start to
create your inbound and outbound rules.

603
00:29:43.740 --> 00:29:47.070
And this is where you can define
who is allowed to connect where.

604
00:29:47.070 --> 00:29:51.375
And it's configure just like those access
control lists we used to use on endpoints.

605
00:29:51.375 --> 00:29:52.705
It's done the same way here.

606
00:29:52.705 --> 00:29:54.695
So I've got this one big allow rule for
3389RDP.

607
00:29:54.695 --> 00:30:00.095
But we can come in and tweak that
based on source and destination.

608
00:30:00.095 --> 00:30:03.365
So you can control access
between two different VMs and

609
00:30:03.365 --> 00:30:04.875
start to limit and restrict that.

610
00:30:04.875 --> 00:30:08.305
This is a great firewall solution and
it's built right into Azure so

611
00:30:08.305 --> 00:30:10.645
we don't have to deploy
a machine to do it.

612
00:30:10.645 --> 00:30:14.020
No whipping up a PFMs or
checkpoint firewall or

613
00:30:14.020 --> 00:30:16.470
whatever it is that you wanted to
play up in Azure, we don't have it.

614
00:30:16.470 --> 00:30:20.500
Those are available, you could do that but
we don't usually have to.

615
00:30:20.500 --> 00:30:21.080
>> No, it's great.

616
00:30:21.080 --> 00:30:22.090
I already supplied some,

617
00:30:22.090 --> 00:30:26.160
I don't have to provision another
virtual machine to make that happen.

618
00:30:26.160 --> 00:30:30.020
So one less computer I gotta worried
about, configure or manage and

619
00:30:30.020 --> 00:30:34.790
having my storage full and
pay for is obviously the big one.

620
00:30:34.790 --> 00:30:37.890
Nice feature built in for us there, Don,
is there anything else that we need to go

621
00:30:37.890 --> 00:30:41.390
over when it comes to either security or
just virtual networks in general?

622
00:30:41.390 --> 00:30:43.750
>> I think those are the main things,
we've got a lot of flexibility,

623
00:30:43.750 --> 00:30:46.250
you can ignore all of this if you want and
just deploy your VMs and

624
00:30:46.250 --> 00:30:49.090
let Microsoft auto-assign it,
that does work.

625
00:30:49.090 --> 00:30:51.370
But if I want multiple VMs that
are all on the same network,

626
00:30:51.370 --> 00:30:54.890
they can see each other and communicate
directly, this is a great way to do it,

627
00:30:54.890 --> 00:30:57.520
we can customize those subnets,
get them put in place,

628
00:30:57.520 --> 00:31:01.500
use network security groups to secure
them, and you end up with a really great,

629
00:31:01.500 --> 00:31:06.230
super flexible environment that can fail
between zones in one of the regions, and

630
00:31:06.230 --> 00:31:09.780
you get high availability, and things
really work just very, very smoothly.

631
00:31:09.780 --> 00:31:11.110
It's the way that Microsoft intended it.

632
00:31:11.110 --> 00:31:13.430
So definitely something that
you wanna take advantage of.

633
00:31:13.430 --> 00:31:15.180
>> Awesome.
Well, thank you so much for

634
00:31:15.180 --> 00:31:18.560
showing us how to work with these
virtual networks and get them deployed

635
00:31:18.560 --> 00:31:22.030
It's something that we might actually
wanna do as we work through Azure.

636
00:31:22.030 --> 00:31:24.140
That being said, we're gonna go ahead and
close down the show.

637
00:31:24.140 --> 00:31:25.660
Thank you guys so much for watching.

638
00:31:25.660 --> 00:31:29.090
Signing off for ITPro TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

639
00:31:29.090 --> 00:31:29.840
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

640
00:31:29.840 --> 00:31:31.123
>> We'll see you next time.

641
00:31:31.123 --> 00:31:34.061
[MUSIC]

642
00:31:34.061 --> 00:31:37.020
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain how to use Load Balancing to increase productivity, reliability, and redundancy. They start by explaining the concept of load balancing and then move right into using features in Azure to implement load balancing in a variety of ways. Specific Azure load balancing technologies include DNS round-robin, Azure Traffic Manager, and Azure Load-Balanced Sets.
episodes.title: Load Balancing
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.782 --> 00:00:16.151
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.151 --> 00:00:18.880
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

4
00:00:18.880 --> 00:00:22.230
we are continuing now with our
Azure virtual machine series.

5
00:00:22.230 --> 00:00:25.860
And joining me in the studio today
is our good friend Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:25.860 --> 00:00:27.770
Don, welcome to the show,
how are you doing today, sir?

7
00:00:27.770 --> 00:00:28.610
>> I'm doing great, Daniel.

8
00:00:28.610 --> 00:00:30.010
Thanks for having me back and

9
00:00:30.010 --> 00:00:33.080
ready to jump right back into the exciting
world of Azure virtual machines.

10
00:00:33.080 --> 00:00:36.040
And today we're gonna be talking about
something that is kind of important.

11
00:00:36.040 --> 00:00:39.399
It is really,
load balancing inside of Azure.

12
00:00:39.399 --> 00:00:43.495
One of the cool parts about having your
virtual machines up in the Azure Cloud

13
00:00:43.495 --> 00:00:45.287
is that you can have one, or ten,

14
00:00:45.287 --> 00:00:48.690
or a thousand virtual machines up and
running at the same time.

15
00:00:48.690 --> 00:00:52.070
And if they're all providing
the same service, like all,

16
00:00:52.070 --> 00:00:55.890
maybe it's a hundred web servers that
all have a copy of your web site, we can

17
00:00:55.890 --> 00:00:59.056
balance traffic across them and there's
a lot of different benefits for that.

18
00:00:59.056 --> 00:01:03.120
So we're gonna talk about why we want to
do that and how we can do it, cuz believe

19
00:01:03.120 --> 00:01:05.910
it or not, there's actually more than
one way we can do that load balancing.

20
00:01:05.910 --> 00:01:08.990
So we'll get a chance to see that in
action right here in this episode.

21
00:01:08.990 --> 00:01:11.710
>> Yeah Don, I'm really looking
forward to this because my uncle Bill,

22
00:01:11.710 --> 00:01:15.200
he's got a website and he only has one
server and it seems to work just fine.

23
00:01:15.200 --> 00:01:19.190
I don't see the whole reason, obviously
there's reasons when you get a large

24
00:01:19.190 --> 00:01:22.360
enough site, traffic starts to
really bog the server down, and

25
00:01:22.360 --> 00:01:24.405
that's when we need to add more servers,
right?

26
00:01:24.405 --> 00:01:27.502
>> Absolutely, one of the biggest
advantages we have with Azure is the fact

27
00:01:27.502 --> 00:01:30.445
that you get access not to just one
of Microsoft's data centers, but

28
00:01:30.445 --> 00:01:31.633
all of their data centers.

29
00:01:31.633 --> 00:01:34.949
And you don't just have to
have one virtual machine,

30
00:01:34.949 --> 00:01:40.260
you can spin up two or three or a hundred,
and that's how you get redundancy.

31
00:01:40.260 --> 00:01:44.370
So if I have one web server and it's
right here in the building with us and

32
00:01:44.370 --> 00:01:47.960
we lose our power or we lose our Internet
or whatever that one web server is down.

33
00:01:47.960 --> 00:01:52.130
And it doesn't matter how much RAM it
has or how many power supplies it has.

34
00:01:52.130 --> 00:01:55.080
If that server is down,
it's not working and that's it, right?

35
00:01:55.080 --> 00:01:57.920
Well, I could buy a second server and
stick it right beside the one here on

36
00:01:57.920 --> 00:02:01.610
the floor, well that's good, if one
server fails I've got the other one.

37
00:02:01.610 --> 00:02:04.810
That's great, but I could still lose
power, I could still lose network,

38
00:02:04.810 --> 00:02:07.510
I could still lose those things,
now both of my servers go off.

39
00:02:07.510 --> 00:02:11.820
So having servers in more than one data
center, that's even better, right?

40
00:02:11.820 --> 00:02:16.500
Now I get geo-redundancy,
if an entire data center fails, big deal,

41
00:02:16.500 --> 00:02:19.890
I've got web servers in other data
centers, I use web servers as an example.

42
00:02:19.890 --> 00:02:23.290
These could be email servers,
file servers, could be databases,

43
00:02:23.290 --> 00:02:24.470
whatever it is you want.

44
00:02:24.470 --> 00:02:27.260
We want to spread them out geographically.

45
00:02:27.260 --> 00:02:30.840
The big problem is, if we go back
to the old enterprise model, right,

46
00:02:30.840 --> 00:02:34.120
so, I worked for a lot of enterprises
that were set up the the old way.

47
00:02:34.120 --> 00:02:37.820
Which is where you had a primary data
center and that was where everything was.

48
00:02:37.820 --> 00:02:40.080
And then you had a disaster recovery
center somewhere else, right?

49
00:02:40.080 --> 00:02:43.691
So your DR, that was a data
center that had servers in it but

50
00:02:43.691 --> 00:02:46.590
they basically sat there
idling all the time.

51
00:02:46.590 --> 00:02:49.980
And you were replicating data to them,
sending your backups over there, and when

52
00:02:49.980 --> 00:02:55.130
a failure happened, it was like you'd flip
a switch and turn on that DR location.

53
00:02:55.130 --> 00:02:58.650
It would come up and you'd run from over
there, but the whole rest of the time,

54
00:02:58.650 --> 00:02:59.592
if you never had a failure,

55
00:02:59.592 --> 00:03:03.710
the DR center just sat there,
just sat there costing you money, right?

56
00:03:03.710 --> 00:03:06.890
Costing you electricity or storage or
whatever it is you're paying for

57
00:03:06.890 --> 00:03:09.900
that over there, but for
the most part, it didn't do anything.

58
00:03:09.900 --> 00:03:13.760
And so the negative there is you've got
to pay a lot for this center that you may

59
00:03:13.760 --> 00:03:16.890
never use, if you never have a failure,
you're never going to turn it on, right?

60
00:03:16.890 --> 00:03:20.510
And then kinda failing over and failing
back was always a challenge, but with

61
00:03:20.510 --> 00:03:24.040
Azure, because it's not our data center,
we don't have to pay for that, right?

62
00:03:24.040 --> 00:03:25.930
We pay for our virtual machines,

63
00:03:25.930 --> 00:03:29.290
I can have my server spread across
these locations and have them be hot.

64
00:03:29.290 --> 00:03:31.770
Have them up and running.

65
00:03:31.770 --> 00:03:33.900
The problem there is I need
to take advantage of it,

66
00:03:33.900 --> 00:03:37.440
I need to distribute my end users across
these different data centers, but

67
00:03:37.440 --> 00:03:39.680
I don't want them to know about it, right?

68
00:03:39.680 --> 00:03:43.090
When I advertise a link, like itpro.tv,
when you go to our website,

69
00:03:43.090 --> 00:03:45.210
ITProTV, well, it's one website.

70
00:03:45.210 --> 00:03:47.770
It doesn't matter where you are in
the world, you go to this one website,

71
00:03:47.770 --> 00:03:51.210
I don't say, oh, if you're in the US,
you should go to us.itpro.tv.

72
00:03:51.210 --> 00:03:54.897
But if you're in Europe,
I want you to go to eu.itpro.tv, and oh,

73
00:03:54.897 --> 00:03:57.260
if the US one fails,
just go over to eu.it.

74
00:03:57.260 --> 00:03:59.940
You don't wanna tell
that to your end users.

75
00:03:59.940 --> 00:04:03.195
So we need a way to make this invisible,
make it transparent where the users don't

76
00:04:03.195 --> 00:04:06.423
even know about it but they're being
balanced across more than one data center.

77
00:04:06.423 --> 00:04:10.475
Or on a minimum, they're just being
balanced across more than one virtual

78
00:04:10.475 --> 00:04:13.625
machine so that if one fails,
the other can take over, but

79
00:04:13.625 --> 00:04:15.968
also that I can scale
out as far as as I want.

80
00:04:15.968 --> 00:04:19.470
Remember, in Azure,
you've got scaling up versus scaling out.

81
00:04:19.470 --> 00:04:22.590
Scaling up is where I say I got one
web server, like Daniel's example,

82
00:04:22.590 --> 00:04:24.680
I got one web server and
it's got eight gigs of RAM.

83
00:04:24.680 --> 00:04:27.470
And it starts getting a little busy,
it starts slowing down.

84
00:04:27.470 --> 00:04:29.160
So I bump it up to 16 gigs of RAM, and

85
00:04:29.160 --> 00:04:33.180
then it starts getting a little slow
again so I bump it up to 32 gigs of RAM.

86
00:04:33.180 --> 00:04:36.788
That's scaling up, and in Azure you can do
that, you can scale up whenever you want,

87
00:04:36.788 --> 00:04:38.107
right, but there's a limit.

88
00:04:38.107 --> 00:04:41.766
Eventually you hit the highest
limit available in Azure, and

89
00:04:41.766 --> 00:04:42.968
what do you do then?

90
00:04:42.968 --> 00:04:45.370
You're out of luck right?

91
00:04:45.370 --> 00:04:49.350
So the secret to using Azure properly
is not to get to that point, right?

92
00:04:49.350 --> 00:04:54.481
Don't bother with scaling up,
if you started with a lower end instance,

93
00:04:54.481 --> 00:04:59.635
maybe you have a DS 1 or something,
right, or just a standard instance.

94
00:04:59.635 --> 00:05:02.285
Well, when you start
running low on memory,

95
00:05:02.285 --> 00:05:07.400
instead of increasing the memory on that
one server, add a second server, right?

96
00:05:07.400 --> 00:05:11.340
The cost usually works out to being about
the same, but now you've got two servers,

97
00:05:11.340 --> 00:05:13.300
you get redundancy in addition to benefit.

98
00:05:13.300 --> 00:05:16.370
And then when those start to get
a little slow, you add a third one and

99
00:05:16.370 --> 00:05:18.830
then you add a fourth one, you add
a fifth and you grow and grow and grow.

100
00:05:18.830 --> 00:05:22.270
And you can do it manually like I'm about
to show you, or you can do a automatic.

101
00:05:22.270 --> 00:05:24.020
We're gonna have
an episode on autoscaling,

102
00:05:24.020 --> 00:05:25.120
where it happens automatically.

103
00:05:25.120 --> 00:05:29.780
And that's neat, because when we grow
it manually we add these servers, and

104
00:05:29.780 --> 00:05:32.490
we might be responding to
some peak time usage, right?

105
00:05:32.490 --> 00:05:37.180
Maybe you work for a retail store, and
the holiday season comes around and

106
00:05:37.180 --> 00:05:41.030
you know your servers get busy because
more people are shopping for Black Friday,

107
00:05:41.030 --> 00:05:42.690
Christmas gifts, stuff like that, right?

108
00:05:42.690 --> 00:05:46.440
So you add more servers, well that's fine
but then at the end of the holiday season

109
00:05:46.440 --> 00:05:48.895
you have to remember to take those
servers away, right, that's manual.

110
00:05:48.895 --> 00:05:51.060
With auto-scaling it
happens automatically,

111
00:05:51.060 --> 00:05:52.490
it automatically adds more servers and

112
00:05:52.490 --> 00:05:55.670
when they're no longer needed it takes
them away, and you save money, right?

113
00:05:55.670 --> 00:05:59.470
But either way,
from the moment you have two servers

114
00:05:59.470 --> 00:06:03.350
you need some way to balance traffic
across those, whether it's manual or

115
00:06:03.350 --> 00:06:06.350
automatic, either way you've
gotta find a way to balance it.

116
00:06:06.350 --> 00:06:10.570
And in Azure there's actually three
different ways that we can provide that,

117
00:06:10.570 --> 00:06:12.260
each one has it's pros and cons.

118
00:06:12.260 --> 00:06:16.120
Some are easy, some are hard,
some cost more money, some are free, but

119
00:06:16.120 --> 00:06:18.770
you've gotta decide which one you use and
oftentimes you'll use more than one.

120
00:06:18.770 --> 00:06:22.570
So in this episode I wanna show you each
of the different mechanisms that we can

121
00:06:22.570 --> 00:06:24.320
use to balance across those.

122
00:06:24.320 --> 00:06:28.349
>> Now Don, using your web server idea,
the picture you've painted for us,

123
00:06:28.349 --> 00:06:31.855
if I've got multiple web servers, I know
for a fact that if I've got a network and

124
00:06:31.855 --> 00:06:34.685
I've got computers on them,
they have to have unique names.

125
00:06:34.685 --> 00:06:36.135
So that's why you were saying, oh,

126
00:06:36.135 --> 00:06:40.625
I don't want to tell you to go
to us.itpro.tv or eu.itpro.tv.

127
00:06:40.625 --> 00:06:46.540
Even though those names are probably
legit, how do I say, go to itpro.tv and

128
00:06:46.540 --> 00:06:49.810
it goes to one and not the other,
how does it know how to do that?

129
00:06:49.810 --> 00:06:54.040
>> So, the first way is probably
the easiest, it kinda ties to what you

130
00:06:54.040 --> 00:06:57.610
are saying which is, it's just doing
what's called DNS round robin, right?

131
00:06:57.610 --> 00:07:00.140
When somebody comes to your web site,
so we'll take our site for example,

132
00:07:00.140 --> 00:07:04.080
when you go to itpro.tv,
your computer does a DNS lookup.

133
00:07:04.080 --> 00:07:07.130
It does a lookup against the DNS server,
and the DNS server says oh,

134
00:07:07.130 --> 00:07:08.160
you wanna get to that website?

135
00:07:08.160 --> 00:07:10.874
Here's the IP address that you go to,
and it provides you an IP, and

136
00:07:10.874 --> 00:07:12.838
you go go that address and
that's that, right?

137
00:07:12.838 --> 00:07:14.417
And it's as simple as that.

138
00:07:14.417 --> 00:07:20.580
Well, when you query a DNS server, it
doesn't have to return just one address.

139
00:07:20.580 --> 00:07:24.890
It could return more than one address,
and if it returns more than one address,

140
00:07:24.890 --> 00:07:26.280
what happens, what do you do?

141
00:07:26.280 --> 00:07:30.370
Well DNS servers, by default,
do what's called round robin, and

142
00:07:30.370 --> 00:07:33.860
so let's say I had three IP
addresses listed for my website.

143
00:07:33.860 --> 00:07:37.910
It might present address number one to me,
and then Daniel does a lookup and

144
00:07:37.910 --> 00:07:40.570
it presents address number two, and
then somebody else does a lookup and

145
00:07:40.570 --> 00:07:43.070
it presents address number three,
all right?

146
00:07:43.070 --> 00:07:47.141
That's not a part of Azure, that's just
a part of DNS, that's how DNS works, so

147
00:07:47.141 --> 00:07:50.927
DNS round robining is built into the DNS
infrastructure that's out there.

148
00:07:50.927 --> 00:07:54.578
So whether you have Azure or whether you
have your own hosted DNS or whatever,

149
00:07:54.578 --> 00:07:58.860
it doesn't matter, you just add more
than one IP address, For your host name.

150
00:07:58.860 --> 00:08:00.400
And now you get round robining.

151
00:08:00.400 --> 00:08:03.160
Now that's cheap,
it's free for most people.

152
00:08:03.160 --> 00:08:05.810
All your doing is adding IP
addresses to your DNS entry.

153
00:08:05.810 --> 00:08:10.550
It's super easy, cuz again, you're just
adding IP addresses, no big deal, right?

154
00:08:10.550 --> 00:08:13.280
There must be something wrong with
it if it's cheap and easy, right?

155
00:08:13.280 --> 00:08:17.690
Well the thing that's wrong with it, is
that it can't sense if a failure occurs.

156
00:08:17.690 --> 00:08:22.200
So if I have three servers and I've got
all three IPs listed from my host name.

157
00:08:22.200 --> 00:08:24.900
When people do a lookup,
they'll get one of those three.

158
00:08:24.900 --> 00:08:27.260
But what if that one host fails?

159
00:08:27.260 --> 00:08:29.085
Well, if I have three servers,

160
00:08:29.085 --> 00:08:32.270
one-third of my visitors are gonna
get sent to that bad server.

161
00:08:32.270 --> 00:08:35.510
And then maybe they'll do the lookup again
and get one of the other servers, and

162
00:08:35.510 --> 00:08:36.810
then they'll come in, right?

163
00:08:36.810 --> 00:08:41.260
But DNS round robining's biggest problem,
is that it doesn't see a failure.

164
00:08:41.260 --> 00:08:43.520
And so for
most people it's not suitable to use.

165
00:08:43.520 --> 00:08:44.880
Well I should correct that.

166
00:08:44.880 --> 00:08:47.350

00:29:43.310 --> 00:29:46.900
managing that endpoint, and there we go.

619
00:29:46.900 --> 00:29:50.020
And so now my LOAD-BALANCED SET NAME
is populated.

620
00:29:50.020 --> 00:29:54.740
And I can go to my other server and
go to its endpoints, and

621
00:29:54.740 --> 00:29:56.550
I'm gonna add an endpoint
on my other server.

622
00:29:56.550 --> 00:29:59.970
Remember, I couldn't add HTTP a moment
ago cuz there was a conflict, right.

623
00:29:59.970 --> 00:30:03.840
So I'm gonna add this time, and when I
go to add I get a STAND-ALONE ENDPOINT,

624
00:30:03.840 --> 00:30:08.782
that's the default, or ADD AN ENDPOINT
TO AN EXISTING LOAD-BALANCED SET.

625
00:30:08.782 --> 00:30:11.740
I wanna add it to my
itprotv-web load balancer.

626
00:30:11.740 --> 00:30:13.108
And on my next page,
I see the configuration, and

627
00:30:13.108 --> 00:30:13.864
see how I can't change it?

628
00:30:13.864 --> 00:30:21.271
I can't edit this stuff because
it's tied to the load balancer.

629
00:30:21.271 --> 00:30:25.146
And so I can come up here and
just give it a name, I'll call mine HTTP.

630
00:30:25.146 --> 00:30:27.621
And then you can try and reconfigure it,
but see [LAUGH] it says,

631
00:30:27.621 --> 00:30:30.859
You can't reconfigure direct server
return for existing load-balanced sets.

632
00:30:30.859 --> 00:30:32.436
What is that talking about?

633
00:30:32.436 --> 00:30:36.134
Well, RECONFIGURE THE LOAD-BALANCED SET
says I wanna redefine it,

634
00:30:36.134 --> 00:30:37.646
I wanna change these ports.

635
00:30:37.646 --> 00:30:39.810
And it will go and change the other ones.

636
00:30:39.810 --> 00:30:43.460
ENABLE DIRECT SERVER RETURN,
this is actually a special feature,

637
00:30:43.460 --> 00:30:44.590
it's designed for SQL Server.

638
00:30:44.590 --> 00:30:47.560
So if you're not load balancing for
SQL, I'm load balancing for

639
00:30:47.560 --> 00:30:49.230
web access here, right?

640
00:30:49.230 --> 00:30:52.371
If you're not load-balancing for SQL, this
option means absolutely nothing to you,

641
00:30:52.371 --> 00:30:53.312
you don't care about it.

642
00:30:53.312 --> 00:30:55.570
Right, it only applies to Microsoft SQL.

643
00:30:55.570 --> 00:30:58.340
In Microsoft SQL,
the SQL Server native client,

644
00:30:58.340 --> 00:31:01.860
it's actually aware of all the nodes
that are behind a load-balanced set.

645
00:31:01.860 --> 00:31:05.238
Normally your end users have no
idea there's more than one node.

646
00:31:05.238 --> 00:31:07.740
But with SQL it always wants
to make sure that you run your

647
00:31:07.740 --> 00:31:09.360
query on the same server.

648
00:31:09.360 --> 00:31:11.429
It doesn't want you jumping
servers mid-query, right,

649
00:31:11.429 --> 00:31:13.000
cuz you can break a transaction.

650
00:31:13.000 --> 00:31:15.730
And so it always wants to directly
connect to the server that it

651
00:31:15.730 --> 00:31:16.620
initially connected to.

652
00:31:16.620 --> 00:31:20.260
So, you might reach out
to a random server, but

653
00:31:20.260 --> 00:31:23.350
then that server will tell you, hey,
in the future just connect directly to me.

654
00:31:23.350 --> 00:31:26.650
It's called direct server return,
and that's really useful with SQL.

655
00:31:26.650 --> 00:31:30.200
But if you're not using SQL,
you don't need that and you won't use it.

656
00:31:30.200 --> 00:31:34.730
Even if you are using SQL, unless you're
using, it's called the SQL Server AlwaysOn

657
00:31:34.730 --> 00:31:37.630
functionality, if you're not using that,
then this still doesn't do anything.

658
00:31:37.630 --> 00:31:39.060
So most people aren't gonna want it.

659
00:31:39.060 --> 00:31:42.883
But you have to turn it on when you
create the availability set, and

660
00:31:42.883 --> 00:31:43.980
I didn't do that.

661
00:31:43.980 --> 00:31:46.791
And since I didn't turn it on, now I don't
even have the option to turn it on, right,

662
00:31:46.791 --> 00:31:47.977
you had to do it when it was created.

663
00:31:47.977 --> 00:31:50.614
>> You get one shot at that monkey and
if you don't take advantage of it,

664
00:31:50.614 --> 00:31:51.396
it's over for you.

665
00:31:51.396 --> 00:31:53.804
>> Yep, now the funny part,
you might have noticed this Daniel,

666
00:31:53.804 --> 00:31:56.540
there was no check mark for me to
turn it on earlier, was there, right?

667
00:31:56.540 --> 00:31:58.350
You have to do it from the PowerShell.

668
00:31:58.350 --> 00:32:00.460
But here they give you
a GUI that isn't useful.

669
00:32:00.460 --> 00:32:03.598
So I don't know why they did that,
exactly.

670
00:32:03.598 --> 00:32:05.572
Actually, if we reconfigure it, can we-
>> They had to rub it in your face.

671
00:32:05.572 --> 00:32:06.951
>> No, that doesn't work either.

672
00:32:06.951 --> 00:32:08.377
All right, I'm gonna leave that off.

673
00:32:08.377 --> 00:32:11.830
[LAUGH] So anyhow,
I'll just go ahead and finish that up.

674
00:32:11.830 --> 00:32:14.605
And instead of complaining,

675
00:32:14.605 --> 00:32:19.494
it now let me add HTTP Port
80 in the load balancer.

676
00:32:19.494 --> 00:32:21.524
I now have two nodes in this group,

677
00:32:21.524 --> 00:32:25.376
in this cloud service,
that are both listening on port 80, and

678
00:32:25.376 --> 00:32:29.460
anybody who goes to the cloud service
will get balanced across them.

679
00:32:29.460 --> 00:32:36.245
So, if I go to my cloud service and I take
itprorotv-web, It's got a URL, right?

680
00:32:36.245 --> 00:32:41.795
It's got an address that you can browse to
which actually was on the other screen,

681
00:32:41.795 --> 00:32:44.699
but it's here too somewhere buried away.

682
00:32:44.699 --> 00:32:45.335
Here we go.

683
00:32:45.335 --> 00:32:50.252
So here is our public virtual IP
address for this cloud service, and

684
00:32:50.252 --> 00:32:54.754
I can go and I can set itprotv's
DNS record to point to this IP.

685
00:32:54.754 --> 00:32:56.749
And anybody going to this IP on port 80,

686
00:32:56.749 --> 00:32:58.972
will get load bounced
across those two nodes.

687
00:32:58.972 --> 00:33:02.089
Or I could add a third, a forth,
a fifth, I could add ten, a hundred, and

688
00:33:02.089 --> 00:33:05.229
people would get load bounced across
all of those and access the website.

689
00:33:05.229 --> 00:33:07.921
And if one of them went down it
would get yanked from the pool.

690
00:33:07.921 --> 00:33:13.532
And as I look here at my input end point,
see how I've got Itprotv-web01 and

691
00:33:13.532 --> 00:33:17.029
itprotv-web02, both on port 80, right?

692
00:33:17.029 --> 00:33:20.880
So I've got two of them listing on
port 80 and they're up and healthy.

693
00:33:20.880 --> 00:33:26.917
Itprotv-web01 has SSH enabled on port
22 but itprotv-web02 couldn't use that.

694
00:33:26.917 --> 00:33:30.672
The port was already taken, and so,
it randomly generated a port for

695
00:33:30.672 --> 00:33:32.112
SSH 62343, right?

696
00:33:32.112 --> 00:33:33.839
That's what normally happens,
that's not load balancing.

697
00:33:33.839 --> 00:33:35.799
We need to connect
the individual node there.

698
00:33:35.799 --> 00:33:39.754
Port 80 is being load balanced and
now we're in business, right?

699
00:33:39.754 --> 00:33:41.809
So, pretty neat,
not that hard to get setup,

700
00:33:41.809 --> 00:33:43.824
you just kinda through
remember where to go.

701
00:33:43.824 --> 00:33:46.561
And this functionality will get put
into the new Azure portal eventually and

702
00:33:46.561 --> 00:33:48.028
then you'll be able to do it from there.

703
00:33:48.028 --> 00:33:51.400
But for right now,
it's better to cover it here.

704
00:33:51.400 --> 00:33:52.688
If you wanna do in the new portal,

705
00:33:52.688 --> 00:33:55.090
well you might want to do it for
resource manager type groups.

706
00:33:55.090 --> 00:33:58.200
And for that you'll end up having to
go to the PowerShell, at least for now.

707
00:33:58.200 --> 00:34:00.540
They'll work it into the UI eventually.

708
00:34:00.540 --> 00:34:04.013
But once it's up and running, it's up,
it's happy, it's ready to go.

709
00:34:04.013 --> 00:34:04.951
Now we're load balancing.

710
00:34:04.951 --> 00:34:07.305
>> Obviously there's a lot of
functionality, a lot of power,

711
00:34:07.305 --> 00:34:09.160
that is involved with load balancing.

712
00:34:09.160 --> 00:34:13.940
As your system, your environment grows and
starts needing to have

713
00:34:13.940 --> 00:34:16.920
access to more resources,
load balance is a great way to go.

714
00:34:16.920 --> 00:34:20.695
So when Uncle Bill and his website for,
he sells beards for dogs, so

715
00:34:20.695 --> 00:34:24.086
obviously that's up and
coming, that's blowing up soon.

716
00:34:24.086 --> 00:34:24.945
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

717
00:34:24.945 --> 00:34:27.026
he's gonna need these functionalities.

718
00:34:27.026 --> 00:34:28.893
>> Yeah, have him call me
when it's beards for cats.

719
00:34:28.893 --> 00:34:29.738
>> Yeah, that's right.

720
00:34:29.738 --> 00:34:30.467
Allen's a cat guy.

721
00:34:30.467 --> 00:34:31.388
>> That's up and coming in my world.

722
00:34:31.388 --> 00:34:34.116
>> [LAUGH]
>> So anyhow, load balancing,

723
00:34:34.116 --> 00:34:35.727
it's pretty easy to turn on.

724
00:34:35.727 --> 00:34:37.583
It doesn't cost a bunch of extra money or
anything.

725
00:34:37.583 --> 00:34:39.218
It's traffic you're getting anyway, right?

726
00:34:39.218 --> 00:34:40.644
So this factors into that.

727
00:34:40.644 --> 00:34:43.311
It is tied to the cloud service, so
a couple little gotchas in there with

728
00:34:43.311 --> 00:34:45.900
the configuration, but
it's definitely something you wanna use.

729
00:34:45.900 --> 00:34:50.049
And if you've got one server with 8 gigs
of RAM, consider going to two servers with

730
00:34:50.049 --> 00:34:53.920
4 gigs of RAM because at a minimum,
you wouldn't get anymore performance.

731
00:34:53.920 --> 00:34:58.216
Same performance as you got before but
now you get some added resiliency.

732
00:34:58.216 --> 00:35:00.863
If one of those nodes goes down,
at least the other one's still up,

733
00:35:00.863 --> 00:35:02.170
you just run a little bit slower.

734
00:35:02.170 --> 00:35:03.381
So big advantages there.

735
00:35:03.381 --> 00:35:05.576
This is definitely something
you'll make use of, and

736
00:35:05.576 --> 00:35:07.924
one of the big advantages of
having your servers in Azure.

737
00:35:07.924 --> 00:35:09.229
>> Awesome.
Well thank you so much for

738
00:35:09.229 --> 00:35:10.241
explaining this to us Don.

739
00:35:10.241 --> 00:35:15.195
It's obviously something that we are Going
to eventually need to use if not already

740
00:35:15.195 --> 00:35:16.480
and into that water.

741
00:35:16.480 --> 00:35:18.290
So, take advantage of this episode,

742
00:35:18.290 --> 00:35:20.840
watch it a few times cuz I know
there's a lot of information in there.

743
00:35:20.840 --> 00:35:25.416
Soak that in, let it permeate through the
pores until it becomes a part of you and

744
00:35:25.416 --> 00:35:30.217
you can easily spin up some of these load
balancing services available from Azure.

745
00:35:30.217 --> 00:35:31.817
Again, thank you, Don,
for explaining this.

746
00:35:31.817 --> 00:35:34.090
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITPro TV.

747
00:35:34.090 --> 00:35:35.230
Thank you for watching.

748
00:35:35.230 --> 00:35:36.516
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrey.

749
00:35:36.516 --> 00:35:37.608
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

750
00:35:37.608 --> 00:35:38.662
>> And we'll see you next time.

751
00:35:38.662 --> 00:35:44.940
>> [MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don take a look at Availability Sets in Microsoft Azure. They begin by explaining what an availability set is exactly and why it's important for Azure users. Then they explain the concepts that go along with availability sets, concepts like Fault Domains(FD) and Update Domains(UD). Lastly they show you how to configure Availability Sets for your Virtual Machines in Azure.
episodes.title: Availability Sets
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.212 --> 00:00:17.420
All right, greetings, everyone and welcome
to another fantastic episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:17.420 --> 00:00:19.600
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

4
00:00:19.600 --> 00:00:22.980
well, we are continuing on with
our Azure Virtual Machine series.

5
00:00:22.980 --> 00:00:26.830
Joining me again in the studio today
is our good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:26.830 --> 00:00:27.880
Don, welcome back to the show.

7
00:00:27.880 --> 00:00:29.130
How you doing, sir?

8
00:00:29.130 --> 00:00:31.460
>> I'm doing great, Daniel,
thanks for having me back, and

9
00:00:31.460 --> 00:00:32.962
I'm ready to jump back into Azure VM.

10
00:00:32.962 --> 00:00:36.440
In this episode, we're gonna talk
about a very misunderstood technology.

11
00:00:36.440 --> 00:00:39.040
It's called an availability set, and

12
00:00:39.040 --> 00:00:41.640
it's one of the times where
we kind of break the rules.

13
00:00:41.640 --> 00:00:45.030
Have you ever watched a movie and there'll
be an actor or actress in the movie, and

14
00:00:45.030 --> 00:00:48.020
all of a sudden they look at the camera,
they start talking to you.

15
00:00:48.020 --> 00:00:50.080
They call that breaking the fourth wall.

16
00:00:50.080 --> 00:00:54.420
Well, in the Azure cloud,
all the hardware that's behind the scene,

17
00:00:54.420 --> 00:00:57.770
that's hidden from us,
we never see that, until now.

18
00:00:57.770 --> 00:01:01.220
This is the one time we break down
that wall and we get a chance to see

19
00:01:01.220 --> 00:01:05.320
just a little bit about the hardware
that's running under the hood.

20
00:01:05.320 --> 00:01:08.620
And we need to do that to make
sure our systems are up and

21
00:01:08.620 --> 00:01:13.950
online as much as possible to maintain
our availability across our Azure cloud.

22
00:01:13.950 --> 00:01:16.860
So that's what we're gonna get a chance
to see here today, availability sets.

23
00:01:16.860 --> 00:01:17.730
It's gonna be a good time.

24
00:01:17.730 --> 00:01:20.200
>> Yeah, Don, now we were
discussing this before the show,

25
00:01:20.200 --> 00:01:22.690
kind of like going over what
we were gonna talk about.

26
00:01:22.690 --> 00:01:26.998
And I wondered, how is this any different,
I mean, Microsoft is backing up all

27
00:01:26.998 --> 00:01:31.587
my virtual machines, they're making sure
that that data is always at least there.

28
00:01:31.587 --> 00:01:34.463
They're not going to lose my data,
that would be bad for them,

29
00:01:34.463 --> 00:01:36.830
they would lose a lot
of business doing that.

30
00:01:36.830 --> 00:01:41.504
How is that any different, or is this
any different than that, should I say?

31
00:01:41.504 --> 00:01:44.000
>> Yeah, so
Microsoft is backing up your VMs.

32
00:01:44.000 --> 00:01:47.577
They are storing the backup as
a snapshot in another location, right,

33
00:01:47.577 --> 00:01:50.860
in at least another availability zone,
if not another region.

34
00:01:50.860 --> 00:01:53.320
And so if there's a hardware failure,

35
00:01:53.320 --> 00:01:57.675
if the hard drives that your VM is
running on die, if the whole server dies,

36
00:01:57.675 --> 00:02:00.290
that they can quickly bring
you up on another system.

37
00:02:00.290 --> 00:02:02.030
Here's the problem.

38
00:02:02.030 --> 00:02:05.700
When that server dies,
you lose what's in RAM.

39
00:02:05.700 --> 00:02:07.740
And that means when they move
you over to another server,

40
00:02:07.740 --> 00:02:08.980
they've got to boot your system up.

41
00:02:08.980 --> 00:02:11.040
Well, how long does it take
your system to boot up?

42
00:02:11.040 --> 00:02:12.980
Might take a minute, minute and
a half, two minutes.

43
00:02:12.980 --> 00:02:14.970
It depends on the size of the instance and
so

44
00:02:14.970 --> 00:02:18.130
on, if data has to actually be
pulled from backup, all that stuff.

45
00:02:18.130 --> 00:02:20.700
But it usually comes up
within a few minutes.

46
00:02:20.700 --> 00:02:25.560
The problem here is that Microsoft has
an SLA, a service-level agreement,

47
00:02:25.560 --> 00:02:26.790
with you the customer.

48
00:02:26.790 --> 00:02:30.904
And Microsoft's SLA is 99.95%, so

49
00:02:30.904 --> 00:02:35.712
they want to guarantee you 99.95% up time.

50
00:02:35.712 --> 00:02:40.986
And what that means is that, spread
out over the course of a year, they're

51
00:02:40.986 --> 00:02:46.633
promising that you will have no more than
4 hours and 22 minutes of down time.

52
00:02:46.633 --> 00:02:48.360
Okay, now 4 hours and 22 minutes,

53
00:02:48.360 --> 00:02:50.880
that sounds like a lot,
I could have quite a bit.

54
00:02:50.880 --> 00:02:54.930
But if you spread that out over months and
take it down into individual days,

55
00:02:54.930 --> 00:02:57.680
it works out to being
less than a minute a day.

56
00:02:57.680 --> 00:03:00.580
So you will have less than a minute
of downtime per day if you kinda

57
00:03:00.580 --> 00:03:01.950
calculate out the SLA.

58
00:03:01.950 --> 00:03:05.900
Well, a single reboot can take more
than a minute, so there goes the SLA.

59
00:03:05.900 --> 00:03:08.650
If you have a couple of these
reboots throughout the year,

60
00:03:08.650 --> 00:03:11.590
you can start to eat that
time up pretty quickly.

61
00:03:11.590 --> 00:03:15.100
So how does Microsoft
safely maintain that SLA?

62
00:03:15.100 --> 00:03:17.630
Well, the backup and
recovery stuff, that's one way.

63
00:03:17.630 --> 00:03:19.380
They know they can have
your server back up and

64
00:03:19.380 --> 00:03:21.770
going in just a matter of
minutes in another region.

65
00:03:21.770 --> 00:03:25.120
But wouldn't it be nice if
that didn't happen at all?

66
00:03:25.120 --> 00:03:27.380
Wouldn't it be nice if
there was no failure?

67
00:03:27.380 --> 00:03:30.420
And remember, I keep saying failures,
it's not necessarily a failure.

68
00:03:30.420 --> 00:03:34.660
Remember that your virtual machine is
running on top of Hyper-V servers.

69
00:03:34.660 --> 00:03:36.890
It's running on top of physical servers.

70
00:03:36.890 --> 00:03:38.540
And those servers have to get updated and

71
00:03:38.540 --> 00:03:41.050
those servers have to
get rebooted sometimes.

72
00:03:41.050 --> 00:03:44.180
And when the server reboots,
what happens to the VM?

73
00:03:44.180 --> 00:03:48.600
Well, the VM's gotta get shifted off to
other hardware, or the VM reboots also.

74
00:03:48.600 --> 00:03:51.320
They might do a frozen snapshot so
that when the system comes back up,

75
00:03:51.320 --> 00:03:52.670
it doesn't know it rebooted.

76
00:03:52.670 --> 00:03:55.770
But for a few moments it was frozen
while the underlying host rebooted.

77
00:03:55.770 --> 00:04:00.410
So, how do we guard against
that affecting our VMs?

78
00:04:00.410 --> 00:04:02.750
Well if I can't see
the hardware underneath,

79
00:04:02.750 --> 00:04:06.080
if I have no control over those updates,
I can't.

80
00:04:06.080 --> 00:04:08.080
And for most people,
that is the case, you can't,

81
00:04:08.080 --> 00:04:09.546
there's nothing you can do about it.

82
00:04:09.546 --> 00:04:13.470
Except, we have one technology called
an availability set that helps with that.

83
00:04:13.470 --> 00:04:16.030
Let me show you a little
diagram that I whipped up.

84
00:04:16.030 --> 00:04:18.885
It's one of my amazing little
art projects that I do and-

85
00:04:18.885 --> 00:04:20.867
>> It's real Andy Warhol, [LAUGH].

86
00:04:20.867 --> 00:04:21.640

539
00:25:29.490 --> 00:25:34.850
full 99.95% SLA, which is not a great SLA,
but it's a good SLA.

540
00:25:34.850 --> 00:25:37.580
>> Well, Don, obviously this is a real
good thing that we need to be able to

541
00:25:37.580 --> 00:25:41.100
understand because like you said before,
if we don't do this,

542
00:25:41.100 --> 00:25:43.590
that SLA gets checked to the window.

543
00:25:43.590 --> 00:25:46.200
Microsoft is gonna say hey,
you kinda out of luck there, buddy.

544
00:25:46.200 --> 00:25:50.890
You didn't follow proper procedures so
we can't guarantee that level of uptime.

545
00:25:50.890 --> 00:25:53.840
So, it's a really important thing
that you understand how this works,

546
00:25:53.840 --> 00:25:57.290
that you're able to do it, so
that you can get that SLA.

547
00:25:57.290 --> 00:25:58.060
Now, Don, that being said,

548
00:25:58.060 --> 00:25:59.970
is there anything else that we
need to know about this for

549
00:25:59.970 --> 00:26:01.420
this particular episode?

550
00:26:01.420 --> 00:26:02.275
>> That's basically it.

551
00:26:02.275 --> 00:26:06.110
This is one of those little owner's manual
type items that you just need to be

552
00:26:06.110 --> 00:26:07.260
aware of, put it on your checklist,

553
00:26:07.260 --> 00:26:11.140
that when you deploy virtual machines
make sure you assign an availability set.

554
00:26:11.140 --> 00:26:12.520
And if you've already got VMs out there,

555
00:26:12.520 --> 00:26:14.430
you may need to add them
to an availability set.

556
00:26:14.430 --> 00:26:17.720
A lot of people don't realize it,
don't know that functionality's there.

557
00:26:17.720 --> 00:26:21.900
And I guess it's worth mentioning also
that if your using Azure Traffic Manager

558
00:26:21.900 --> 00:26:26.040
or DNS Round Robining and bouncing across
resources in different regions, then you

559
00:26:26.040 --> 00:26:30.410
might not care about the FDs and UDs
because if you're in different regions,

560
00:26:30.410 --> 00:26:33.050
you're guaranteed to be
in separate FDs and UDs.

561
00:26:33.050 --> 00:26:36.290
But if you've got resources
to deployed in one region,

562
00:26:36.290 --> 00:26:37.380
this is something you need to be aware of.

563
00:26:37.380 --> 00:26:39.480
It's definitely something
that you need to configure.

564
00:26:39.480 --> 00:26:40.540
>> All right, well, excellent Don.

565
00:26:40.540 --> 00:26:44.000
Thank you so much for explaining this to
us, very important topic for us to know.

566
00:26:44.000 --> 00:26:47.080
That's being said, I guess it's time
to go ahead and close the show.

567
00:26:47.080 --> 00:26:48.610
Thank you guys so much for watching.

568
00:26:48.610 --> 00:26:50.400
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV,

569
00:26:50.400 --> 00:26:52.330
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

570
00:26:52.330 --> 00:26:52.890
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

571
00:26:52.890 --> 00:26:54.882
>> And we'll see you next time.

572

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain and demonstrate how to autoscale your Azure Virtual Machine environment. Autoscaling is a great way to make sure that an expected level of performance is being achieved as well as saving you money. Here Don and Daniel show you how to configure autoscaling, which includes setting up triggers(CPU, Queues, and Schedules) and attaching to an Availability Group. They also cover best practices concepts when setting up your autoscaling systems.
episodes.title: Autoscaling
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.044 --> 00:00:16.201
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.201 --> 00:00:20.050
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and
on today's episode well we are continuing

4
00:00:20.050 --> 00:00:23.530
on that Azure Virtual Machine series that
we've been working so hard on, and joining

5
00:00:23.530 --> 00:00:27.570
us in the studio again today is none other
than our good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:27.570 --> 00:00:29.030
Don, welcome to the show, sir.

7
00:00:29.030 --> 00:00:29.910
How you doing today?

8
00:00:29.910 --> 00:00:30.940
>> I am doing great, Daniel.

9
00:00:30.940 --> 00:00:33.230
And I'm excited to be back into Azure VM,

10
00:00:33.230 --> 00:00:36.400
because today we're gonna look
at a technology that I think is

11
00:00:36.400 --> 00:00:40.150
just one of the key shining features
of having our servers up in the cloud.

12
00:00:40.150 --> 00:00:42.020
And that's auto scaling.

13
00:00:42.020 --> 00:00:45.720
We're gonna take a look at how
we can dynamically power up and

14
00:00:45.720 --> 00:00:49.160
power down virtual machines
as we need them, which is

15
00:00:49.160 --> 00:00:52.570
really where we start to get our money's
worth out of using a cloud service.

16
00:00:52.570 --> 00:00:55.340
You know,
we've seen in all of our earlier episodes,

17
00:00:55.340 --> 00:00:57.380
there's a lot of benefits to
putting our stuff in the cloud.

18
00:00:57.380 --> 00:01:02.110
The multiple data centers, the power and
network redundancy, the state of

19
00:01:02.110 --> 00:01:05.170
the art network operations center
that's monitoring all this equipment.

20
00:01:05.170 --> 00:01:06.690
All of those benefits.

21
00:01:06.690 --> 00:01:08.880
But I think this one, autoscaling,

22
00:01:08.880 --> 00:01:12.420
is probably one of the greatest benefits
cuz it's the one that can save some money.

23
00:01:12.420 --> 00:01:14.890
And when you're trying to
sell a service to your CIO or

24
00:01:14.890 --> 00:01:18.160
your IT director,
usually it's what it boils down to is hey,

25
00:01:18.160 --> 00:01:21.750
if I have my stuff on site, I have control
over it, I know how much it costs.

26
00:01:21.750 --> 00:01:24.650
When I put it in the cloud there's risk,
but if you can show me where it saves

27
00:01:24.650 --> 00:01:27.610
money, then it's an easy decision,
let's get ourselves up in the cloud.

28
00:01:27.610 --> 00:01:29.540
So, that's what we're going
to take a look at today and

29
00:01:29.540 --> 00:01:31.380
you'll see that it's pretty
easy to get deployed.

30
00:01:31.380 --> 00:01:35.280
>> Yeah, our CIO used to have a motto he
lived by, he said, I wanna save money,

31
00:01:35.280 --> 00:01:36.395
because money saving is good.

32
00:01:36.395 --> 00:01:39.540
[LAUGH] And you know what,
I tended to agree with him.

33
00:01:39.540 --> 00:01:44.960
This is a very awesome, actually, beyond
the fact it's going to save you money,

34
00:01:44.960 --> 00:01:47.550
which is obviously a good thing.

35
00:01:47.550 --> 00:01:52.070
But it's just a really cool technology
to say, hey grow when I need to grow and

36
00:01:52.070 --> 00:01:54.560
shrink when I need to shrink and
do that for me.

37
00:01:54.560 --> 00:01:56.520
I don't wanna have to administrate this.

38
00:01:56.520 --> 00:01:58.670
I'm just gonna set it,
forget it and walk away from it and

39
00:01:58.670 --> 00:02:02.100
I know that when I need CPU,
if I need more, if I need this, that or

40
00:02:02.100 --> 00:02:04.730
the other,
it's gonna just auto do that for me.

41
00:02:04.730 --> 00:02:07.200
Now it comes on the question Don is,
how do we do that and

42
00:02:07.200 --> 00:02:08.370
that's what our show is about today,
right?

43
00:02:08.370 --> 00:02:09.340
>> Absolutely, yup.

44
00:02:09.340 --> 00:02:12.460
So let's start off really basic here
with just how auto-scaling works,

45
00:02:12.460 --> 00:02:13.755
then we'll see how set it up.

46
00:02:13.755 --> 00:02:15.530
Kinda understand how it works.

47
00:02:15.530 --> 00:02:19.090
Now in our early episodes, if you've been
watching them, we covered things like

48
00:02:19.090 --> 00:02:22.610
setting up load balance sets, and
setting up availability group.

49
00:02:22.610 --> 00:02:25.740
Those are important because when it comes
to auto-scaling you're gonna need both.

50
00:02:25.740 --> 00:02:29.070
Auto scaling doesn't work well by itself,
in fact, it doesn't work at all by itself.

51
00:02:29.070 --> 00:02:33.840
It has to be combined with an availability
set and a load balancing set.

52
00:02:33.840 --> 00:02:36.500
Right now, remember,
an availability set, what is that?

53
00:02:36.500 --> 00:02:40.790
That's the different locations of
hardware in the Microsoft Datacenter.

54
00:02:40.790 --> 00:02:43.610
And when we start to deploy our hardware
you have these fault domains and

55
00:02:43.610 --> 00:02:45.760
update domains that your stuff
is getting spread across.

56
00:02:45.760 --> 00:02:49.470
If you're not familiar with these terms,
jump over and check our episode out on

57
00:02:49.470 --> 00:02:52.880
availability sets, we did a whole episode
on that, providing that infrastructure.

58
00:02:52.880 --> 00:02:57.620
So once you've got that in place,
then you can create a load balancing set.

59
00:02:57.620 --> 00:03:00.640
And a load balancing set is where
we distributed our traffic across

60
00:03:00.640 --> 00:03:01.600
multiple servers.

61
00:03:01.600 --> 00:03:04.240
Now, I've got a classic
Don diagram here and

62
00:03:04.240 --> 00:03:07.920
I went to the Salvador Dali School of Art,
so it's not beautiful or anything.

63
00:03:07.920 --> 00:03:09.990
But I was just trying to demonstrate
how we handle the load balancing.

64
00:03:09.990 --> 00:03:12.180
And you'll see where I've got
these three servers over here.

65
00:03:12.180 --> 00:03:14.720
These would be like virtual
machines that are up in Azure.

66
00:03:14.720 --> 00:03:17.530
And my users from the Internet
are coming in, and

67
00:03:17.530 --> 00:03:20.030
I wanna spread that traffic
across these three nodes.

68
00:03:20.030 --> 00:03:24.600
Maybe I know that my network gets so
busy at some points

69
00:03:24.600 --> 00:03:26.990
that I need three virtual machines
to be able to handle the load,

70
00:03:26.990 --> 00:03:30.170
that one virtual machine couldn't handle
the load on its own so I go to three.

71
00:03:30.170 --> 00:03:32.210
Well, I need something to
distribute that load and

72
00:03:32.210 --> 00:03:36.750
that something is going to either be a
load balance set or Azure Traffic Manager.

73
00:03:36.750 --> 00:03:39.980
One or the other or you might use a
combination of the two depending how many

74
00:03:39.980 --> 00:03:43.990
regions you span across, but that's kind
of a key piece and that's part of Azure.

75
00:03:43.990 --> 00:03:47.240
So, if you haven't watched our episode
on load balance sets definitely

76
00:03:47.240 --> 00:03:49.280
check that one out,
we kinda show how to set that up.

77
00:03:49.280 --> 00:03:51.790
But basically, we're distributing
traffic across these three nodes.

78
00:03:51.790 --> 00:03:53.590
Now that works great.

79
00:03:53.590 --> 00:03:57.570
But, I know my system needs
three servers at peak time.

80
00:03:58.720 --> 00:04:00.580
Am I always at peak time?

81
00:04:00.580 --> 00:04:02.610
No.
Sometimes, the system slows down.

82
00:04:02.610 --> 00:04:04.700
You've got these ebbs and flows.

83
00:04:04.700 --> 00:04:07.110
If you deal in like retail for example.

84
00:04:07.110 --> 00:04:09.670
You know the holiday season
you get really busy.

85
00:04:09.670 --> 00:04:12.080
And then during the regular seasons,
it gets slower.

86
00:04:12.080 --> 00:04:14.650
So you might need more servers at
some time and less on the others.

87
00:04:14.650 --> 00:04:16.700
Now that, that's not a year model.

88
00:04:16.700 --> 00:04:18.930
You could even go down to
an individual day, right?

89
00:04:18.930 --> 00:04:20.770
You, you could go to us, ITProTV.

90
00:04:20.770 --> 00:04:25.140
Our site gets really busy
during the day on weekdays.

91
00:04:25.140 --> 00:04:29.480
So on weekdays, from about eight am
until about eight pm, cause of the,

92
00:04:29.480 --> 00:04:31.487
the US East Coast, West Coast, you know.

93
00:04:31.487 --> 00:04:33.390
A lot of our viewers are here in the US.

94
00:04:33.390 --> 00:04:37.713
So we get high traffic from eight am to
eight pm our time, Monday through Friday,

95
00:04:37.713 --> 00:04:40.828
then from eight pm to eight am,
right, overnight for us,

96
00:04:40.828 --> 00:04:45.279
that's when the rest of the world is awake
and so we have Australians and people from

97
00:04:45.279 --> 00:04:49.940
England and all them start jumping in
the system, but that's not as many people.

98
00:04:49.940 --> 00:04:52.260
Hence we don't need as many servers,
right?

99
00:04:52.260 --> 00:04:56.300
And then on Saturday and Sunday on the
weekends, well our traffic really starts

100
00:04:56.300 --> 00:04:58.520
to drop down cuz people don't
like to study on the weekends.

101
00:04:58.520 --> 00:05:00.930
So we need even less
servers on the weekends.

102
00:05:00.930 --> 00:05:04.840
Well in this model, I've got three servers
that are up and I'm paying for all three.

103
00:05:04.840 --> 00:05:07.290
All the time,
whether I'm using them or not.

104
00:05:07.290 --> 00:05:10.510
Whether I've got enough traffic to
saturate all three servers or whether I've

105
00:05:10.510 --> 00:05:13.790
only got enough traffic to saturate
one server, I'm paying for all three.

106
00:05:13.790 --> 00:05:18.430
And that's because load balance sets
don't really pay attention to whether or

107
00:05:18.430 --> 00:05:20.880
not a server actually has to be used,

108
00:05:20.880 --> 00:05:23.870
it just wants to make sure that
a server's not getting overused.

109
00:05:23.870 --> 00:05:27.200
That's it, that's what the load balance
sets in Azure traffic manager do.

110
00:05:27.200 --> 00:05:32.710
But we can combine that with auto scaling
to start to mirror our utilization.

111
00:05:32.710 --> 00:05:37.040
So let's say on my network, I've got a
system where at midnight things are pretty

112
00:05:37.040 --> 00:05:41.820
slow, and then as we get closer to 6 AM,
traffic kind of peaks, right.

113
00:05:41.820 --> 00:05:44.070
Whatever it is I'm doing,
things get kind of busy in the morning.

114
00:05:44.070 --> 00:05:46.780
And then it slows back down again.

115
00:05:46.780 --> 00:05:50.370
And then right after lunch, so
maybe from noon until about 6PM,

116
00:05:50.370 --> 00:05:55.050
things really start to get busy again and
then it trails off at night, right?

117
00:05:55.050 --> 00:05:57.830
So, for
half the day my network's really busy, for

118
00:05:57.830 --> 00:06:00.050
another half of the day
the network's really slow.

119
00:06:00.050 --> 00:06:02.670
Okay, well the traditional
model is to go out and

120
00:06:02.670 --> 00:06:04.440
buy enough servers to handle your peak.

121
00:06:04.440 --> 00:06:07.620
So let's say it takes me ten
servers to cover the peak.

122
00:06:07.620 --> 00:06:09.300
So now I've got ten servers.

123
00:06:09.300 --> 00:06:11.170
And these can be virtual machines,
it can be physical servers,

124
00:06:11.170 --> 00:06:11.890
it doesn't really matter.

125
00:06:11.890 --> 00:06:13.500
I've got to have ten to cover it, right.

126
00:06:13.500 --> 00:06:18.430
And that way my network doesn't get
slow when I hit one of these peaks, but

127
00:06:18.430 --> 00:06:19.880
during these times.

128
00:06:19.880 --> 00:06:21.748
Maybe two or
three servers could handle the load and

129
00:06:21.748 --> 00:06:24.410
now I've got seven servers
sitting there doing nothing.

130
00:06:24.410 --> 00:06:26.970
Well, in the old days when I was buying
physical servers I didn't have a choice.

131
00:06:26.970 --> 00:06:29.100
I had to buy the physical servers and
yeah, they just sat there and

132
00:06:29.100 --> 00:06:30.000
did nothing during those times.

133
00:06:30.000 --> 00:06:31.980
That was it, it was all I could do.

134
00:06:31.980 --> 00:06:35.290
But in the cloud world,
these are just virtual machines.

135
00:06:35.290 --> 00:06:38.340
Microsoft has the hardware on the back
end and I'm paying for what I use.

136
00:06:38.340 --> 00:06:41.260
I'm paying for the time that I've
got that machine up and running.

137
00:06:41.260 --> 00:06:46.020
So during this time I could
shut some servers down right?

138
00:06:46.020 --> 00:06:48.390
Instead of having 10 servers I
could shut seven of them down and

139
00:06:48.390 --> 00:06:52.350
go down to three servers and
now I'm only paying for three servers.

140
00:06:52.350 --> 00:06:54.880
And then as things get busy
I can turn them back on.

141
00:06:54.880 --> 00:06:57.810
The problem is,
I'd have to do that by hand right?

142
00:06:57.810 --> 00:06:59.610
And if we were talking
about a yearly model.

143
00:06:59.610 --> 00:07:02.460
Hey I know the holiday season is coming
up, things are going to get busy,

144
00:07:02.460 --> 00:07:04.030
yeah give me some turn them on,
that's great.

145
00:07:04.030 --> 00:07:04.750
Right?

146
00:07:04.750 --> 00:07:08.910
But if I want to do this hour by hour,
I gotta free up my schedule, right?

147
00:07:08.910 --> 00:07:10.910
I gotta just sit here and
watch this thing like a hawk and

148
00:07:10.910 --> 00:07:12.410
spin these things up as you go.

149
00:07:12.410 --> 00:07:18.210
So what auto scaling does is it makes
this happen automatically, right?

150
00:07:18.210 --> 00:07:22.410
So if I need ten servers at my peak,
it'll give me ten servers at my peak.

151
00:07:22.410 --> 00:07:26.100
And if I only need two servers,
it'll shut eight of them down so

152
00:07:26.100 --> 00:07:29.230
that I've only got two up and
running, and then it will grow.

153
00:07:29.230 --> 00:07:32.500
And it does it on its own, and
I don't have to worry about it.

154
00:07:32.500 --> 00:07:36.360
And this can significantly
reduce your bill with Azure,

155
00:07:36.360 --> 00:07:41.230
right, because when you shut those servers
down, you still pay for storage, right,

156
00:07:41.230 --> 00:07:44.580
cuz the hard drives, they take up space,
so you are still taking up storage.

157
00:07:44.580 --> 00:07:46.885
But the CPU, the RAM,
the network bandwidth,

158
00:07:46.885 --> 00:07:50.801
that all gets returned to Microsoft, and
they rent that out to other people and so

159
00:07:50.801 --> 00:07:53.640
you're not paying for
it anymore you pay for what you use.

160
00:07:53.640 --> 00:07:58.181
This is a big, big, big advantage
over having your own hardware.

161
00:07:58.181 --> 00:08:02.693
When you have your own hardware
you pay for 100% of it on day one.

162
00:08:02.693 --> 00:08:06.233
But with Azure you just pay for
what you use over time.

163
00:08:06.233 --> 00:08:10.534
And maybe some day it'll break even
with if you had bought your own physical

164
00:08:10.534 --> 00:08:11.154
servers.

165
00:08:11.154 --> 00:08:14.386
But usually by that point it's time
to buy new physical servers and

166
00:08:14.386 --> 00:08:16.870
you end up saving money,
you save quite a bit.

167
00:08:16.870 --> 00:08:19.740
>> And money saving is good,
at least that's what I hear and

168
00:08:19.740 --> 00:08:20.750
that's the word on the street.

169
00:08:20.750 --> 00:08:26.190
Now Don, the question now becomes, how
does it know That it's time to scale up?

170
00:08:26.190 --> 00:08:29.470
How does it know to add more CPU or
add another server or

171
00:08:29.470 --> 00:08:32.950
do any of the things that we need it to do
to give us the increase in performance.

172
00:08:32.950 --> 00:08:34.310
>> Well,
that's where we get involved, right.

173
00:08:34.310 --> 00:08:34.910
We have to teach it.

174
00:08:34.910 --> 00:08:35.535
We have to tell it.

175
00:08:35.535 --> 00:08:37.200
Cuz it's not gonna watch for
this stuff by default, right.

176
00:08:37.200 --> 00:08:41.130
So if you want to get auto scaling set up,
there's three steps, right?

177
00:08:41.130 --> 00:08:43.770
First, you've gotta have
an availability set.

178
00:08:43.770 --> 00:08:46.060
Right, this is actually built
off of the availability set.

179
00:08:46.060 --> 00:08:47.510
So you have to have those, right.

180
00:08:47.510 --> 00:08:49.770
If you haven't defined one,
then this isn't gonna work.

181
00:08:49.770 --> 00:08:53.290
And the availability sets
are not created by default.

182
00:08:53.290 --> 00:08:56.460
When you start spinning up your VMs,
it doesn't put them into a set.

183
00:08:56.460 --> 00:08:57.760
So you gotta make sure you have that.

184
