00:29:31.550 --> 00:29:35.050
So when I defined this, I said right here,
my instance range starts at two and

639
00:29:35.050 --> 00:29:36.140
goes as high as five.

640
00:29:36.140 --> 00:29:38.260
My web server's doing
absolutely nothing right now.

641
00:29:38.260 --> 00:29:42.430
So I should be at two nodes, and
then it'll start to add more, or

642
00:29:42.430 --> 00:29:43.720
it might be shutting one down,

643
00:29:43.720 --> 00:29:46.760
or whatever, it starts to react, but
mine shouldn't be shutting down.

644
00:29:46.760 --> 00:29:50.930
In fact, if I jump over to my instances,
let's just take a look, and sure enough,

645
00:29:50.930 --> 00:29:52.660
I've got one guy running.

646
00:29:52.660 --> 00:29:57.410
I've got one guy stopped and de-allocated,
and three more that are running.

647
00:29:57.410 --> 00:29:58.380
Why do I have four running?

648
00:29:59.410 --> 00:30:03.680
When I told it to step down only
by one node every ten minutes, and

649
00:30:03.680 --> 00:30:07.580
this episode's only a thirty
minute episode so it stopped one.

650
00:30:07.580 --> 00:30:10.800
If we wait around for ten more
minutes it'll stop another one, and

651
00:30:10.800 --> 00:30:13.720
then another one until
there's only two left, right?

652
00:30:13.720 --> 00:30:16.840
So it's already scaling for me,
it's already shut one down and

653
00:30:16.840 --> 00:30:18.040
it's starting to work through the others.

654
00:30:18.040 --> 00:30:22.110
And when it says deallocated, that means
that the virtual machine still exists, but

655
00:30:22.110 --> 00:30:25.070
it's not consuming RAM,
it's not consuming CPU.

656
00:30:25.070 --> 00:30:28.580
A lot of people don't realize this,
if you log into your virtual machine and

657
00:30:28.580 --> 00:30:29.410
you just start and shut down.

658
00:30:29.410 --> 00:30:31.790
And you shut it down,
it will stay stopped here.

659
00:30:31.790 --> 00:30:32.820
But it won't say deallocated.

660
00:30:32.820 --> 00:30:35.450
And that means you're still
reserving the CPU and RAM.

661
00:30:35.450 --> 00:30:37.680
You're still paying the per minute fee,
even though you shut it down.

662
00:30:38.770 --> 00:30:42.230
Deallocated means it shut down and

663
00:30:42.230 --> 00:30:46.870
you gave the RAM and CPU and all that
back to Microsoft user paying storage.

664
00:30:46.870 --> 00:30:50.110
And so now I'm paying storage for
that node.

665
00:30:50.110 --> 00:30:53.675
Here is the only caveat I need to throw
in there, the one word of warning.

666
00:30:54.770 --> 00:30:56.340
This is a web farm.

667
00:30:56.340 --> 00:30:57.540
I'm load balancing across it.

668
00:30:57.540 --> 00:31:00.540
When users come to visit my web app
they're getting distributed across these

669
00:31:00.540 --> 00:31:01.470
five instances.

670
00:31:02.830 --> 00:31:05.150
What if I wanna make
a change to my website?

671
00:31:05.150 --> 00:31:07.380
Well, I got five copies
of the website here, but

672
00:31:07.380 --> 00:31:08.660
some of my notes are gonna be stopped.

673
00:31:10.140 --> 00:31:12.700
I need to update them, so
I need to turn them on, boot them up?

674
00:31:12.700 --> 00:31:15.880
Yes, you need to start them up,
go in there and edit the website.

675
00:31:15.880 --> 00:31:17.700
And so that can be a bit of a challenge,
right?

676
00:31:17.700 --> 00:31:19.100
Especially if your website changes a lot.

677
00:31:19.100 --> 00:31:21.860
You're constantly having to spin
up your nodes, update the website.

678
00:31:21.860 --> 00:31:22.940
I got five.

679
00:31:22.940 --> 00:31:23.690
Imagine if you had 100.

680
00:31:23.690 --> 00:31:27.360
I mean,
imagine if this is a really big farm.

681
00:31:27.360 --> 00:31:30.310
Well, what's gonna happen is,
you're not gonna wanna deal with that.

682
00:31:30.310 --> 00:31:31.830
And I had to pre-provision these machines.

683
00:31:31.830 --> 00:31:32.800
I had to create five.

684
00:31:32.800 --> 00:31:34.280
What if I had to create 100?

685
00:31:34.280 --> 00:31:36.280
Well, we'd go to the PowerShell
first off and spin that up.

686
00:31:36.280 --> 00:31:39.280
And you can create your own image that's
already set up the way you want, but

687
00:31:39.280 --> 00:31:42.550
that doesn't help you with your machine
getting out of date, all right?

688
00:31:42.550 --> 00:31:45.630
So there's another technology that,
I'll include a link for

689
00:31:45.630 --> 00:31:50.020
this in the show,
what's called the Custom Script extension.

690
00:31:50.020 --> 00:31:51.830
When you spin up a virtual
machine in Azure,

691
00:31:51.830 --> 00:31:54.650
it asks if you wanna
install the Azure Agent.

692
00:31:54.650 --> 00:31:59.380
And one part of the Azure Agent,
Is the custom script extension.

693
00:31:59.380 --> 00:32:02.760
And what that does is
let you write a script.

694
00:32:02.760 --> 00:32:04.230
It's a PowerShell script.

695
00:32:04.230 --> 00:32:06.920
And you can store it in a storage account.

696
00:32:06.920 --> 00:32:09.140
And you can assign it to
your virtual machines,

697
00:32:09.140 --> 00:32:12.530
so that when your virtual machines
boot up, they run the script.

698
00:32:12.530 --> 00:32:15.800
And so I can have my web servers all
defined, so that when they boot up,

699
00:32:15.800 --> 00:32:19.200
it runs a script, and reaches out and
gets the latest copy of the webpage.

700
00:32:19.200 --> 00:32:24.050
So that machine could've been off for six
months, and then as soon as it spins up,

701
00:32:24.050 --> 00:32:27.640
it runs Windows Update,
it goes in and it grabs those files.

702
00:32:28.650 --> 00:32:30.990
Or maybe I provision
the machine as I need it.

703
00:32:30.990 --> 00:32:33.690
And so I could have it where I just
grab Microsoft's default image, so

704
00:32:33.690 --> 00:32:35.110
it would already be up to date.

705
00:32:35.110 --> 00:32:37.360
And then it runs a script that
customizes it to match my needs.

706
00:32:37.360 --> 00:32:41.240
Installs IIS, adds the webpages,
and then it comes up.

707
00:32:41.240 --> 00:32:42.730
But that way,
your machines are always up to date.

708
00:32:42.730 --> 00:32:46.130
So you'll normally wanna combine auto
scaling with custom script extension.

709
00:32:46.130 --> 00:32:49.400
And that's important to make sure that
your machines are running the latest copy

710
00:32:49.400 --> 00:32:50.500
of your website and updates.

711
00:32:50.500 --> 00:32:51.830
So I'll include,

712
00:32:51.830 --> 00:32:56.840
this is a great article that runs down
how the custom script extension works.

713
00:32:56.840 --> 00:33:00.130
And even gives you some sample
scripts that you can deploy.

714
00:33:00.130 --> 00:33:04.370
And what you'll see is they're basically
creating a script, and then assigning it

715
00:33:04.370 --> 00:33:08.790
to a virtual machine right here, so
that it'll run when the machine boots up.

716
00:33:08.790 --> 00:33:11.300
And any time the machine reboots or
boots up it will run the script,

717
00:33:11.300 --> 00:33:13.740
it will grab the latest copy of the page,
and now it's up to date.

718
00:33:13.740 --> 00:33:16.320
And then it can shut down, and
I don't have to worry about it.

719
00:33:16.320 --> 00:33:18.570
So that's kind of another side of this,
and like I said,

720
00:33:18.570 --> 00:33:20.920
I'll put this link in the show notes.

721
00:33:20.920 --> 00:33:21.690
Excellent stuff Dan.

722
00:33:21.690 --> 00:33:23.600
Obviously auto scaling is going to do,

723
00:33:23.600 --> 00:33:25.510
well one thing it's gonna
save us some money.

724
00:33:25.510 --> 00:33:26.460
We always like that.

725
00:33:26.460 --> 00:33:30.960
But the ability to say, I'm having more
of the, higher than the normal traffic.

726
00:33:30.960 --> 00:33:33.510
Go ahead and auto ramp up for
me, go ahead and

727
00:33:33.510 --> 00:33:36.450
add more servers, add more CPU
whatever it is that you needed to do

728
00:33:36.450 --> 00:33:39.780
to get that back to
a normal performance level.

729
00:33:39.780 --> 00:33:43.200
That is going to be a godsend for
us as administrators, and

730
00:33:43.200 --> 00:33:46.610
our customers' experience is not
gonna suffer from degradation.

731
00:33:46.610 --> 00:33:49.130
Don, is there anything else that we need
to cover in this episode when is comes

732
00:33:49.130 --> 00:33:50.150
to autoscaling?

733
00:33:50.150 --> 00:33:50.740
>> That's basically it.

734
00:33:50.740 --> 00:33:52.270
Just remember, do it.

735
00:33:52.270 --> 00:33:55.010
Right, it's there, it's a feature, you can
turn on autoscale and does not cost you

736
00:33:55.010 --> 00:33:58.452
a dime extra and it saves you money,
you definitely wanna do it.

737
00:33:58.452 --> 00:34:00.640
>> All right well thank you so
much for this explanation Don,

738
00:34:00.640 --> 00:34:02.910
and I'm sure our audience
is thanking you as well.

739
00:34:02.910 --> 00:34:06.230
And we thank you for joining us today,
we're gonna go ahead and sign off for

740
00:34:06.230 --> 00:34:08.860
IT PRO tv
>> I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

741
00:34:08.860 --> 00:34:09.640
>> And I'm Don Pizet.

742
00:34:09.640 --> 00:34:10.967
>> And we'll see you next time.

743

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don discuss backup and recovery options available in an Azure VM environment. They begin by covering the basic topics of disaster recovery and backup best practices and concepts, then go over the technologies that are typically used to perform backup operations; specifically Microsoft System Center Orchestrator, Azure Site Recovery, and Azure Backup. Finally, they show you how to use Azure Backup to take and restore machine.
episodes.title: Backup and Restore
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.064 --> 00:00:10.064
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.645 --> 00:00:16.852
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.852 --> 00:00:18.619
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and

4
00:00:18.619 --> 00:00:22.750
in today's episode we are continuing on
with our Azure Virtual Machine series.

5
00:00:22.750 --> 00:00:24.780
And joining us in the studio today is,
you know him,

6
00:00:24.780 --> 00:00:27.040
you love him, he's our good friend,
Mr. Don Pezet.

7
00:00:27.040 --> 00:00:29.170
Don, welcome back to the show,
how are you doing today, sir?

8
00:00:29.170 --> 00:00:31.370
>> I'm doing great Daniel,
thanks for having me back and

9
00:00:31.370 --> 00:00:34.070
ready to jump right back into
the world of Azure Virtual Machines.

10
00:00:34.070 --> 00:00:38.490
Today we want take a look at backup and
restore options in Microsoft Azure.

11
00:00:38.490 --> 00:00:41.120
And we're gonna talk about
a couple things too.

12
00:00:41.120 --> 00:00:44.770
As far as like backing up and
restoring virtual machines in Azure,

13
00:00:44.770 --> 00:00:46.420
there's not really all
that much you need to do.

14
00:00:46.420 --> 00:00:48.740
You can take images of
a machine if you want.

15
00:00:48.740 --> 00:00:51.260
Microsoft's kind of replicating
your data on the back end,

16
00:00:51.260 --> 00:00:53.380
you just need to back up
your individual data.

17
00:00:53.380 --> 00:00:57.010
So, a lot of what we talk about is
going to apply, that'll work just fine.

18
00:00:57.010 --> 00:01:01.190
But, we also may choose to back up
systems that we have on premises

19
00:01:01.190 --> 00:01:03.120
that aren't even virtual
machines up in Azure.

20
00:01:03.120 --> 00:01:05.040
We just want to back up to Azure and
have them available.

21
00:01:05.040 --> 00:01:08.180
So, we've got a couple of different
approaches we can take this and

22
00:01:08.180 --> 00:01:12.080
fortunately with Microsoft,
the options really work for all the above.

23
00:01:12.080 --> 00:01:14.680
So, you'll see a lot of
examples on Microsoft's site.

24
00:01:14.680 --> 00:01:16.661
Where they'll reference
a back up product for

25
00:01:16.661 --> 00:01:19.280
backing up an on-premises
device into the cloud.

26
00:01:19.280 --> 00:01:22.238
But it works for
backing up your virtual machines also.

27
00:01:22.238 --> 00:01:24.506
And so, we're going to take
a look at some of those options,

28
00:01:24.506 --> 00:01:26.340
some of the various features
that are out there.

29
00:01:26.340 --> 00:01:28.240
And what we can use, what we can do.

30
00:01:28.240 --> 00:01:32.140
And just see which one fits in your model,
cuz there's a lot of choices.

31
00:01:32.140 --> 00:01:36.040
>> Yeah, this should be a very episode
because, if you have an environment at

32
00:01:36.040 --> 00:01:39.950
all, a disaster recovery plan is
something that is a necessity.

33
00:01:39.950 --> 00:01:42.741
This isn't like an afterthought,
when we get around to it,

34
00:01:42.741 --> 00:01:46.690
we'll probably do something about backups,
in case we lose some data.

35
00:01:46.690 --> 00:01:50.250
Think about how sensitive and
how important your data is to you and

36
00:01:50.250 --> 00:01:52.010
what you would do if you lost it.

37
00:01:52.010 --> 00:01:54.900
You would probably freak out,
wig out, and rightfully so.

38
00:01:54.900 --> 00:01:57.690
We'd all be running around
like our head was on fire.

39
00:01:57.690 --> 00:01:59.700
So Don, you're going to help us say hey,

40
00:01:59.700 --> 00:02:03.710
now that Azure is a part of our
environment, how do we dive into that?

41
00:02:03.710 --> 00:02:05.170
How do we start using Azure?

42
00:02:05.170 --> 00:02:09.452
What is their backup utilities and
disaster recovery utilities?

43
00:02:09.452 --> 00:02:13.640
And really, what's the best place to
begin with Azure and backing up things?

44
00:02:13.640 --> 00:02:16.980
>> All right, so the first thing we need
to think about is, when we talk about back

45
00:02:16.980 --> 00:02:22.990
up, there's this difference between
high availability and redundancy.

46
00:02:22.990 --> 00:02:25.150
Or high availability and resiliency.

47
00:02:25.150 --> 00:02:28.020
So, when we talk about
high availability or HA.

48
00:02:28.020 --> 00:02:31.680
That's making sure that if a fault
ever occurs on my network,

49
00:02:31.680 --> 00:02:32.990
that the end users never notice it.

50
00:02:32.990 --> 00:02:34.060
That my servers stay up.

51
00:02:34.060 --> 00:02:36.785
Right, if I have a web server and
the web server fails,

52
00:02:36.785 --> 00:02:40.140
people can't get to my website,
they notice it, right?

53
00:02:40.140 --> 00:02:41.220
If I want high availability,

54
00:02:41.220 --> 00:02:44.550
I need to make sure that when that web
server fails, I still have my website up.

55
00:02:44.550 --> 00:02:46.380
Now how do I achieve that?

56
00:02:46.380 --> 00:02:47.410
More web servers, right?

57
00:02:47.410 --> 00:02:49.730
If I had a second web server,
a third web server.

58
00:02:49.730 --> 00:02:52.860
When the first one fails,
the other two are up and running, and

59
00:02:52.860 --> 00:02:54.390
the end users just go
to the other servers.

60
00:02:54.390 --> 00:02:55.560
So, they don't notice a failure, right?

61
00:02:55.560 --> 00:02:56.970
That's high availability, right?

62
00:02:56.970 --> 00:02:58.390
That gives us protection.

63
00:02:58.390 --> 00:02:59.660
And if you want to learn how to do that,

64
00:02:59.660 --> 00:03:04.180
we've got shows that'll cover load
balance sets, high availability sets, and

65
00:03:04.180 --> 00:03:07.440
a few other things that you combine
to create that environment.

66
00:03:07.440 --> 00:03:12.015
But those are not a replacement for
backups.

67
00:03:12.015 --> 00:03:13.930
Backups are really important because,

68
00:03:13.930 --> 00:03:17.550
what happens if I've got three web
servers that all have my website.

69
00:03:17.550 --> 00:03:20.253
And I'm replicating between them,
right, cuz if I update my website,

70
00:03:20.253 --> 00:03:21.950
I want to update it on all of them.

71
00:03:21.950 --> 00:03:24.802
If I log into one of those servers and
I delete the website by accident,

72
00:03:24.802 --> 00:03:28.180
it's gonna replicate that and
delete from the others, right?

73
00:03:28.180 --> 00:03:31.851
So, I need to be able to go and
restore data from the past.

74
00:03:31.851 --> 00:03:33.844
I need to restore and
recover that information.

75
00:03:33.844 --> 00:03:34.704
So, how can I do that?

76
00:03:34.704 --> 00:03:37.549
How can I recover data from the past?

77
00:03:37.549 --> 00:03:40.749
Well, there's a few different
tools that we've got, and

78
00:03:40.749 --> 00:03:44.790
really it kinda runs the gamut
based on how much control you want.

79
00:03:44.790 --> 00:03:46.840
Now, Microsoft is backing up your server.

80
00:03:46.840 --> 00:03:49.500
They're backing up your Azure VM's,
you don't even have to configure,

81
00:03:49.500 --> 00:03:51.320
you don't even see it,
it's invisible to you.

82
00:03:51.320 --> 00:03:54.416
And, if there's a hardware failure on the
backend where they're not able to recover

83
00:03:54.416 --> 00:03:56.786
the drives, they'll restore
that backup and it's automatic.

84
00:03:56.786 --> 00:04:00.610
So, we don't interact with that at all.

85
00:04:00.610 --> 00:04:03.370
But we can't go back in time.

86
00:04:03.370 --> 00:04:06.940
We can't go back days or
weeks or months or whatever.

87
00:04:06.940 --> 00:04:10.470
We're kind of limited to that most
recent backup that Microsoft has and

88
00:04:10.470 --> 00:04:12.020
we don't even get to see that,
they do it, right?

89
00:04:12.020 --> 00:04:16.150
We can't even trigger that restore if
we want, it's entirely up to Microsoft.

90
00:04:16.150 --> 00:04:20.570
So, if we want to be able to restore
data from the past, what can we do?

91
00:04:20.570 --> 00:04:24.450
Well, you can leverage all of the tools
that are built into your operating system.

92
00:04:24.450 --> 00:04:28.120
So in Microsoft Windows, we have
things like Volume Shadow Copy, right,

93
00:04:28.120 --> 00:04:30.300
the previous versions utility.

94
00:04:30.300 --> 00:04:34.730
And you can turn that on in Windows,
and that'll let you roll back changes,

95
00:04:34.730 --> 00:04:37.030
restore files that have been gone for
a little while.

96
00:04:37.030 --> 00:04:41.550
There's the system restore points,
those work inside of Azure also.

97
00:04:41.550 --> 00:04:45.140
And so you can roll back to restore
points to undo changes that you've made.

98
00:04:45.140 --> 00:04:50.210
So, don't overlook the same utilities
that you're already making use

99
00:04:50.210 --> 00:04:52.200
of in your on-premises servers.

100
00:04:52.200 --> 00:04:55.697
You can use those in Azure too, and now
if somebody accidentally deletes a file,

101
00:04:55.697 --> 00:04:58.650
I don't need some crazy,
special Azure service.

102
00:04:58.650 --> 00:05:02.570
I just go into the previous versions tab
and I restore a file, just like normal.

103
00:05:02.570 --> 00:05:06.990
So, all that stuff from your regular
systems applies right inside of Azure VM.

104
00:05:06.990 --> 00:05:10.240
Right, but
I do want to go a step further and

105
00:05:10.240 --> 00:05:12.975
highlight some of the other backup and
restore options.

106
00:05:12.975 --> 00:05:15.550
Cuz some of them are neat, some of
them do give you some extra powers,

107
00:05:15.550 --> 00:05:16.300
some superpowers.

108
00:05:16.300 --> 00:05:20.015
And so, I wanna show you guys those and
kind of walk you through what's available.

109
00:05:20.015 --> 00:05:24.505
And before I do that, the way you select
which one of these is going to work.

110
00:05:24.505 --> 00:05:26.875
So, I'm going to show you three or
four different solutions.

111
00:05:26.875 --> 00:05:28.045
How do you know which one is right for
you?

112
00:05:28.045 --> 00:05:32.515
Right, there's a couple of concepts you
need to be aware of to pick the right one.

113
00:05:32.515 --> 00:05:35.282
And the first one that I want to talk
to you about is one you'll see in

114
00:05:35.282 --> 00:05:38.302
Microsoft Technet articles all the time,
which are two backup and

115
00:05:38.302 --> 00:05:40.562
recovery terms, RPO and RTO.
